text: tomorrow the equal opportunities commission celebrates its th birthday it was set up in a rush in to coincide with the establishment of the equal pay and sex discrimination acts legislation intended to expedite a new world for women and ethnic minorities initially a sickly child the eoc under its chair of two years julie mellor has begun to show teeth but what of the state of women a quarter of a century ago the nd attempt to get equal pay on to the statute books was finally successfully guided by barbara castle then minister of employment companies were given five years to adjust not untypically one company issued a list of discrimination factors among them the willingness to work overtime the lads were kept ahead of the girls who were instantly handicapped because of the kids at home and now these are contradictory times some say the battle is over others are too exhausted to know while if polemicists are to be believed men have cause to be mad about women with the collapse of heavy industry and the high divorce rate some men argue that they are emasculated and excluded from home and work forced into what was once the womans role secondclass citizen the eoc is using its celebrations to challenge some of this thinking aware that equality for women has always required that men too should be liberated from the straitjacket of gender stereotyping it has commissioned research which analyses how far women and men have actually come does the traditional breadwinner rest in peace an increasing number of men under look after their children its just that they dont call it childcare according to one study of yearolds disagree that a mans job is to earn the money a womans to look after the home and family the eoc is calling for a national debate on how to forge a social contract for the st century between men and women employers and employees government and the electorate one that draws on notions of modern citizenship and builds on labours recognition that childcare and the worklife issue is no longer a private affair but a central part of its economic strategy and a matter of social justice more persuasive than rhetoric however is the clout carried by profit and loss put bluntly the present jalopy of a system in which the average male works a hour week and the family remains invisible costs a packet for instance days lost to stress alone are estimated to cost british industrybn per year at the same time the rewards of those few businesses who are proactive are obvious one recent survey of the ftse companies showed that the quarter who have a stcentury agenda on discrimination and flexibility had shares which on average over a fiveyear period from had risen by compared with the ftse average of in spite of this the pay gap has shifted little since the s it stands at for fulltime female employees but a whopping for m parttimers much attention is paid to the half a million working women out of m who pay tax at the top whack but on average a fulltime man earns a woman as a society mellor says weve accepted equality as part of the wallpaper but in truth weve stagnated class race and qualifications divide women but they have discrimination in common the middle skilled childless woman has a lifetime earnings gap of compared with her male colleague a mother of two pays an extra penalty of if a woman takes a year out to have a family she returns to a job paying less research published by the eoc last week revealed that many employers are complacent about pay only one in five has adopted the eocs voluntary code of practice only have taken a pay audit secrecy hides the crime gail cartmail is equality officer for msf a union with members a third of them female it has just launched an equal pay strategy and what it has already learned about pay scales cartmail says has proved a bit of a shock among underwriters and brokers for instance fulltime women earn p for every earned by a man confidentiality is a requirement of some jobs but we want everybody talking about pay she says unequal pay is about cash job segregation the low value attached to caring the parttime penalty the attitudes of managers and a female tendency to undersell ourselves as part of its valuing women campaign the eoc demonstrated how prejudice remains alive and well among line managers some still see women as less ambitious and committed so they deny them bonusrelated pay the problem is not helped by the weakness in the sex discrimination and equal pay acts it took years for speech therapists to win m in back pay next month the eocs equal pay task force will publish its report it might advise stronger legislation compulsory pay audits and contract compliance what is also required is class action and the clout to demand profound structural change mellor would like a duty placed on the public sector to eradicate discrimination heather wakefield of unison says local government faces a massive equal pay problem exacerbated by the consequences of privatisation the average salary is the average age seven out of employees are women and they are expressing their frustration with their feet equality and flexibility must be part of the solution local authorities say they are unable to fund the the pay gap and wakefield says the government must if it eliminated discrimination it would reduce the national pay gap and set the private sector an example unisons aim at branch level is educate negotiate litigate of course in the long term a critical mass of women entering the workforce is bound to have an impact in they represented a third now they represent half in only of higher education students were female now that figure is in december employment minister tessa jowell gave a thoughtful speech in which she emphasised the need to tackle gender stereotyping in schools to offer retraining to use citizenship lessons to tackle boys attitudes to caring and to listen to equal pay recommendations the government also intends to extend parental rights much more is needed twentyfive years ago equality and space for commitments outside paid work were considered the business of bolshie women now at least they are recognised as the concern of both sexes and issues at the heart of society

text: employers were yesterday accused by the equal opportunities commission of being shockingly complacent over continuing large scale pay inequality after it released evidence of widespread discrimination against women across the workforce an eoc survey of plus large employers found that women were commonly denied access to bonuses and performancerelated pay while more than reported that part time employees mainly women were illegally excluded from pension schemes the hourly earnings of women were on average lower than those of men but the weekly and annual gap was around because of the effect of discrimination over pensions bonuses and performancerelated pay the eoc report found that manufacturing industry had a worse record than the public sector or private services of failing to take action over gender pay inequality while at the same time manufacturing employers were by far the most confident that their pay systems were fair many employers are simply burying their heads in the sand the eoc chairwoman julie mellor said yesterday employers have a major role in eliminating pay discrimination and manufacturing organisations in particular are not doing enough to ensure they are paying women fairly the cbi the main employers organisation last night hit back at the criticism insisting there was little evidence to suggest most firms were operating unfair pay structures there is a pay gap but the reasons for it are much more complex than simple direct discrimination susan anderson the director of cbi human resources policy said research shows the key cause of the pay gap is occupational segregation women are more likely to work in lower paying sectors but ms mellor countered that studies at the london school of economics and for the economic and social research council had found that up to a half of the earnings gap between women and men could be attributed to pay discrimination at work rather than job segregation she added that employers needed to reassess why jobs carried out mainly by women were often worse paid than those done by men the report found that many human resources managers in manufacturing industry regarded maledominated professional technical and skilled manual jobs as having greater intrinsic value than femaledominated support and administrative jobs

text: the government was yesterday criticised by trade unions after it rejected proposals to force employers to review pay by gender in an effort to close the pay gap as a report by the equal opportunities commission confirmed that the uk has the worst record in europe on equal pay ministers made it clear that pay audits would remain voluntary the recommendation which was a key to the studys proposals to abolish the pay gap within eight years is fiercely resisted by business which claims it would create an impossible administrative burden the cbi condemned the proposal as ineffective and disproportionate and insisted that women were paid less mainly because of family responsibilities and their concentration in low paid occupations rather than because of discrimination by employers however the tuc said there was nothing to make bad employers review pay its president bill morris said if you have ruled out any kind of statutory mechanism it does not seem to me that you have got too much going for you because you have ruled out any means of compliance thirtyone years after the passing of the equal pay act the gap between the hourly earnings of women working parttime and men working fulltime has barely changed standing at up to of the pay gap was caused not by occupational segregation or womens share of family responsibilities but by discrimination the study found the recommendations include moves to raise awareness of the pay gap and simplifying the system of equal pay employment tribunals however amid opposition from business ministers will not impose a statutory duty on employers to conduct pay audits insisting that a voluntary approach will work employment minister tessa jowell said we dont think mandatory pay reviews are the way forward as a first step she said the government would review employers moves to narrow the gap annually

text: the government will today be challenged to review womens pay in the public sector as a hardhitting report finds that britains gender pay gap is the worst in the european union thirty years after the equal pay act women in fulltime work are still earning only fourfifths of what men do the equal opportunities commissions equal pay task force will press ministers to compel employers to conduct pay audits to address the gender gap its report just pay will highlight britains place at the bottom of the eu league on equal pay while women working fulltime earn on average of male fulltime hourly earnings up from in parttime female workers receive only of male fulltime hourly wages compared with a european average of the proposal is designed to produce greater pay transparency in businesses which can be expected to resist the measure on grounds of cost and bureaucracy the commission will also call on the government to lead the way in reviewing pay differences on the basis that many low paid occupations dominated by women including nursing caring and cleaning jobs are in the public sector the report will also find that occupations traditionally regarded as womens work are still undervalued in the uk with women working fulltime as nurses earning less than average male hourly earnings other european countries also offer women better maternity rights and significantly better childcare provision the study compiled by a task force including business leaders trade unionists civil servants and academics highlights a problem which the governments womens unit has exposed but which ministers have done little to reverse a year ago the unit published research exposing the female forfeit and concluding that women earn less than men over a lifetime not because they may take time off to bring up children but because of pay discrimination and their concentration in lower paid occupations at the time womens ministers lady jay and tessa jowell stopped short of moves to compel employers to examine pay structures focusing instead on encouraging girls to opt for better paid careers and urging women to ask male colleagues what they earned todays study will confirm both that little has happened since to change the pay gap and that business will strongly resist any requirement to conduct audits a key element in the resistance to the move by some in government a spokeswoman for the cbi said yesterday we dont believe that the pay gap is actually the result of deliberate discrimination by employers we think pay is a far more complex issue than that women had the choice of entering better paid occupations she said the commissions report however argues that the pay gap cannot be explained by womens educational and career choices since often as more women enter a sector the relative pay falls

text: poor baroness jay there she was hoping to hand in her notice as leader of the house of lords and minister for women and tiptoe out of the back door with as little fuss as possible and then those nasty busybodies at the equal opportunities commission complete a survey trumpeting the failure of her womens unit to be fair the findings published today are as much an indictment of new labour as they are of the unit it created to look after womens interests in terms of equal pay and equal opportunities britain is the most sexist place to work in europe red faces all around the party that had raised such hopes and manufactured such hype about its prowomen agenda remember all the boasts about more female mps than ever before the groundbreaking breastfeeding blair babes will now enter the general election with a set of statistics that will further alienate female voters a million of whom say theyve gone off the government the picture is bleak indeed if you care about how your wage packet compares with the man who does the same job as you youre better off in france germany or even portugal the wage gap in these countries is less than in britain where a woman working full time earns just of her male colleagues salary for a parttime female worker that sinks to if you care about paid maternity leave youd better up sticks and move to italy where a mother gets five months paid leave or finland nine months as well as days for paternity leave in britain you get a paltry weeks add to this poor childcare provision and in predominantly female professions such as nursing an average pay of less than overall average male earnings in the uk and you can see why the european council of ministers told the uk to get down to work on closing the pay gap they have their work cut out for them thirty years since the equal pay act was passed women find the workplace as inimical as the factory caricatured in charlie chaplins mod ern times talk to staff at the eoc and they can name endless cases of women who have had to take their employers to court to receive fair treatment take dr lorna chessum a female lecturer at leicesters de montfort university who discovered she had been appointed on a lower salary less than a similarly qualified male colleague she received compensation in an outofcourt settlement in september then theres doreen mcmanus who worked as a payroll administrator for rentokil she claimed that over three years she did the same work as a male colleague whom she trained and who was paid more than her she took the matter up with her employer who agreed to review her pay her salary was increased but she was still earning less than her colleague she lodged an equal pay claim and rentokil settled the case paying her compensation two small victories in a war we thought was won long ago a war in which we cannot count on either government or employer as an ally jill rubery as the co ordinator of the european commissions expert group on gender and equality was present when the commission having seen the uks national action plan for employment last year publicly reprimanded the country for its appalling employment figures immediately our civil servants started to rubbish the data as insufficient and emphasise the high employment rate we have for women which is well above the target by set in lisbon in the spin machine is likely to go into overdrive after the eoc survey too despite its impressive credentials the research was carried out by the nop group in the summer last year it involved a telephone survey of senior human resource managers in organisations with at least employees telephone interviews with national trade union officials and indepth casestudy research in selected organisations while government apologists may spin against the eoc survey for painting too gloomy a picture of the working womans lot critics of the government suspect that the survey in fact lets the government off lightly mary davis who heads the centre for trade union studies at the university of north london argues industry by industry the gender pay gap has actually widened since i see no evidence apart from the introduction of the national minimum wage to support the view that we are wit nessing a narrowing of the gap among workingclass women certainly things have got worse if youre living in a textile town for instance with the industry bottoming out beneath your feet you are far poorer than before rubery who with damian grimshaw carried out the research for the eoc feels that even some of the states povertybusting initiatives have had a negative impact on womens wages the working families tax credit for example contradicted the equalpay ethos by trapping the second incomeearner in a low paying job moreover as both davis and rubery point out a government that believes that any regulation hinders the market and has abdicated all responsibility for pay structure cannot intervene in the one area that most affects the gender pay gap the market indeed has become a fig leaf behind which employers can hide discrimination you can get away with paying jane less than joe by signing them up to individualised contracts there are a million weasel words that allow you to claim that what she is doing is not exactly the same as what he does equally there are many ways of explaining away why promotion keeps eluding her the trade unions once the battering rams for victims of unfair treatment at work have lost their bite collective bargaining has declined in recent years today less than one in three workplaces is covered by it meanwhile employer accountability has grown ever more nebulous in an increasing number of situations there is no single clearcut employer as is the case when work is subcontracted or joint ventures or partnerships operate this makes it difficult to uphold legislationbased on comparable work for the same employer the fragmentation of the public sector through the contracting out of services to the private sector also contributes to the difficulty in monitoring the wage differential not surprisingly this state of affairs gets the thumbs up from employers of those who took part in the eoc survey cheerfully believed their pay systems were fair those of us who feel that if jane and joe carry out the same work they should bring home the same pay packet will simply have to provide fodder for the eocs case studies or move to lisbon this is a version of an article first published in this weeks new statesman

text: picture the scene you are a woman who works alongside a man who does exactly the same job as you in exactly the same office one day you both go for promotion who do you think gets it him of course at least thats what women overwhelmingly believe according to a new survey by recruitment consultancy officeteam most female pas have a perception that their male counterparts will always get promoted faster than them even though its a profession that is femaledominated says sarah thomas who was involved in the research but she insists our study also found that the reality is that there is no truth in this concern whatsoever pas no matter what their gender get promoted on merit indeed similar studies that have been carried out since men started entering the profession have come to the same conclusion that blokes are by no means treated as superior in the secretarial world so why the female fear alison stimpson a careers adviser claims it stems from the fact that men increasingly use support roles as a first rung on their career ladder with around double the number in higher education than a decade ago graduates have had to find news ways into professions secretarial work has proved to be the most popular route particularly for men in other words while it appears that men are megaquick at getting promotion the reality is that they are megaquick at proactively seeking out higher status roles indeed a recent report by the tuc found that the number of men in secretarial jobs has risen by over the past three years and that most of these are graduates alistair smith an analyst in the city is one of them i decided to use a pa role as a steppingstone because i realised id learn far more about business by working daytoday with a top businessman than i ever would have from a graduate trainee scheme where i might be one of people struggling to get noticed i had access to highlevel people and had every intention from day one to have his job one day i succeeded he says meanwhile sarah eldoori of recruitment consultancy office angels believes that rather than men talking themselves into promotion women tend to talk themselves out of it its my experience that female secretaries say things like oh im not that great at my job whereas men boast about their achievements thats the real gender split among support staff this claim is backed by a new study by gallup which found that women are far more likely to underrate their performance at work than men are and that this could be one of the reasons why many women fail to get highranking jobs if as our research reveals womens selfassessments are less positive than those given to them by other people they may not progress as fast as men explains haihai yuan coauthor of the a gallup report on appraisals mick cooper senior lecturer in applied social science at brighton university believes women may have every reason to be worried about the reentry of men into the profession what research hasnt yet concluded is whether its the increased responsibilities and status of secretarial work that has led to more men doing the job or whether the fact that more men do the job has led to the increased responsibilities and status he says if its the latter men are in danger of pushing women back out of the picture consider russia in the s and s he says there was a sudden influx of women becoming doctors and the status of doctors then dropped with men opting out sadly it is still possible for gender to have this kind of influence and what we could be witnessing here is the flip side of the coin in fact as james reed chief executive of reed employment services points out originally secretarial work was restricted to men as mastering a keyboard was felt to be too technical for women forty years ago that trend was reversed and it was seen as almost inevitably a female domain today however its changing again and could theoretically become maledominated once more for now however there appears to be no such threat indeed steven durham pa to the assistant director at camden local education authority says despite men now accounting for of support staff and women panicking that well take over the gender divide has been eradicated in other professions a lot quicker than in the secretarial world i have found for instance that there is a resistance particularly among male employers to employ male support staff a spokesperson from recruitment consultancy marshall tapp agrees five per cent of respondents to one of our surveys said they would not give a mans cv the same consideration as a womans one said he wouldnt consider it because the idea was so odd and another said he would assume that they were homosexual

text: accident insurance for children is an emotive subject no parent can bear to think of their child being hurt and the idea of benefiting financially from a childs injuries is quite abhorrent but nor do parents like the idea of having to fight for compensation if the injuries are serious so a policy that pays out a predetermined sum without quibble in the event of an injury may be a good idea after all if your child loses the use of a leg would come in useful for adapting your home so your child could get around more easily these policies tend to be reasonably low cost boots sells one at a year for one child or for two or more children while ace insurances firstcover policy costs a year for one child or for two or more children the amounts paid out vary considerably firstcover for example will pay up to if your child suffers total paralysis total loss of intellectual capacity total loss of sight in both eyes or the loss of the use of a hand arm or leg above the knee for the loss or loss of use of a lung it would pay kidney and spleen it also pays for educational support for each month a child is unable to attend school up to a year and for each day a child is in hospital but the vast majority of claims are for broken bones which get little in the way of a payout for an arm and for a leg even though parents may have to take time off work to nurse their child but do you really need an accidental injury policy especially when your child is likely to be covered at school by the schools or local councils liability cover debbie gibson a spokeswoman for ace insurance says the policy really comes into its own with more serious injuries when parents might be waiting for a personal injury litigation case to be settled she points to the case of darren coombs see separate text: junior health minister yvette cooper has made history as the first ever minister to take maternity leave on the relatively generous terms of weeks on full pay finally it seems that the department of health has produced its most positive contribution to the public health debate ms cooper is doing something politicians rarely manage which is to lead by example even tony blairs fudged paternity leave after the arrival of baby leo taking things easy for a couple of weeks while refusing to let john prescott actually take the reins of power smacked of a third way that hardly put the new baby or its mother first despite enormous improvements in maternity benefits there is still a lingering suggestion that women who either choose between career and family or who squeeze out babies between meetings and pretend nothing has happened are somehow better employees acres of newsprint were devoted to the case of sue clark director of corporate affairs at scottish power when two years ago she stayed at her desk during labour and was able via the magic of teleconferencing to complete a deal within two days of her baby being born for those of us returning from a leisurely maternity leave even longer than ms coopers this example is enough to make the blood run cold the incessant crying insecurity and constant need for food which follow childbirth makes it impossible for most of us to contemplate returning to work within four or five months and that is even before one takes into account the needs of the baby in ms clarks case she planned only eight weeks off barely time to establish a routine for a newborn but the companys feelings were quite clear everyone in the company appreciates sues determination a scottish power spokesman purred he should have been saying the chief executives furious she put her own health at risk for the sake of a commercial transaction and hes ordered her not to come back for at least six months because the truth is that when you take proper time off after giving birth you actually come back able to handle the real world without bursting into tears or forgetting where you live ms cooper has made history but now she has to follow through announcing you are taking weeks off is one thing actually sticking to it while the phone rings off the hook and ministerial briefings arrive at your door by the cartload is entirely another text: yvette cooper one of labours rising stars is to become the first government minister in britain to take maternity leave in a move hailed last night by maternity rights campaigners ms cooper the public health minister announced that she will take weeks leave on full pay when she gives birth to her second child which is due in august ms cooper who is married to ed balls gordon browns closest adviser plans to stop working in july she will return to work by the end of the year after discussions with the health secretary alan milburn she will take her maternity leave in line with department of health guidelines civil servants in the department are entitled to weeks leave on full pay ms cooper will therefore continue to draw her salary of while she is on leave this is more generous than womens statutory rights by law women are entitled to weeks maternity leave of which is paid six weeks at at full pay and weeks at p a week mr balls who is the treasurys chief economic adviser will take paternity leave as he did when their first child was born ms cooper mp for pontefract and castleford said yesterday that she was planning to have her baby at the nhs hospital in her constituency where she had her first child meriel who is months old we are planning to have the baby in pontefract ms cooper said the nhs staff there were wonderful to us last time round maternity rights campaigners last night congratulated ms cooper for setting a good example to employees and employers alike joanna wade a spokeswoman for the maternity alliance said it is good to know that she feels confident enough to be up front that she will be taking time off we strongly hope that this will set an example to high level employees that there are times when family has to come before work and mothers should not be punished for that ms coopers announcement came as ministers finalise details of a government review of parental rights they are expected to approve an increase in statutory maternity pay and in the amount of time mothers are allowed to take off work campaigners are hoping that tony blair who took two weeks paternity leave after the birth of leo last year will endorse radical changes ms wade said we are very hopeful but there is a danger that the changes may not be as wholehearted as we would have liked to see ms cooper is regarded as one of the brightest stars in the government who is favoured by both the blair and brown camps a former journalist she was appointed to the frontline post of public health minister in two years after her election to parliament

text: twentyfive years ago a tailor called mrs kersten had her brief moment in the limelight when she won a landmark case and was awarded equal pay with a male colleague who had been getting more for doing a similar job eleven years on in a certain ms white a machinist and several female colleagues were also involved in a key case again supported by the equal opportunities commission they too were awarded a pay rise in line with the pay of male upholsterers they worked with the progress of equal opportunities is slow and painful as the eoc celebrates the twentyfifth anniversary of the sex discrimination act it can look back on some important achievements but it is also positioning itself for more fights the eoc points out that in the past years the gap between the proportion of women and men in the labour market has fallen from to per cent the percentage of directors and managers who are women has increased from per cent in to per cent in in the needs of working parents and carers were low on the public policy agenda now employment law includes the right for parents to take time off after the birth of a child or if their child is unwell and improvements have been made to maternity rights and rights for parttimers paternity leave and extended maternity rights are under discussion but there is a long way to go more women than men are in lowskilled lowpaid jobs with little access to vocational training and education per cent of parttime workers are women the same proportion as in at the same time women receive only per cent of mens hourly wages a situation exacerbated for parttime women workers who earn per cent of the average hourly earnings of fulltime male counterparts in a recent european survey on equal pay britain came tenth out of countries julie mellor chair of the eoc says most women are still trapped in a lifecycle of inequality working in lowpaid lowstatus jobs and struggling to combine work and family responsibilities caring for children and older relatives british fathers work the longest hours in europe and many are prevented from spending time with their children we must not think weve made it just because a few women have reached the top of their field and a few employers now offer paternity leave the reality of most peoples everyday lives is still determined by their sex baroness helena kennedy chair of the british council says the reform of working practices for men as well as for women is at the heart of promoting sex equality in the uk over at the commission for racial equality there is a firm belief in the importance of reform in this area the cre is getting ready to put flesh on the bones of a new piece of legislation it is hailing as the biggest shift in employment practice on the race equality front for almost two decades the race relations amendment act alters the act in a way that will it is hoped turn the public sector into a model equal opportunities employer said a cre spokesman the act said thou shalt not discriminate or you may be prosecuted the amended legislation says if you are a public sector employer you must deliver equality of opportunities and here is a code of practice that you must follow home secretary jack straw will be publishing draft regulations for consultation this month the cre plans to publish the draft codes of practice in june or july the cre spokesman said instead of knocking on doors and saying could you ever so kindly work for racial equality we will have a code of practice that the public sector must abide by for instance the police will have a requirement to show that they have fully implemented equal opportunity employment practices as well as showing an equal opportunities commitment in the way they treat the public the nhs too will be among the public sector bodies taking a long hard look at its employment practices last week the cre revealed the details of a survey it carried out into working practices in nhs trusts in the south of england the usual picture emerged the spokesman said people say they are against discrimination but only per cent of the trusts were able to demonstrate good equality programmes this is the nhs which has depended on ethnic minorities to carry the service the newly formed disability rights commission is young enough still to be brighteyed and bushy tailed in its approach to pushing through reforms in the workplace against the background of the disability discrimination act the drc has launched its first major initiative actions speak louder than words part of which involves approaching companies and asking them to make a commitment to promoting equality of opportunity for the disabled over and above the requirements of the act the argument the drc is presenting to business is that there are million disabled people in the uk with a combined income of billion a year so it makes good business sense to be seen as disabledfriendly as well as demonstrating admirable social responsibility organisations backing the campaign include microsoft lloyds tsb the halifax transport company arriva and the tuc microsofts commitment involves links with online recruitment company totaljobscom and disability charity leonard cheshire to launch a webbased service for disabled people seeking a new career the site is expected to open in early summer the halifax has committed itself to increasing the number of people with learning disabilities it employs initially at its head office the initiative underlines the drcs emphasis on communication as well as litigation drc chairman bert massie says we have learned a lot from the eoc experience we have not had to be so litigious we started out with statutory codes of practice so have not had to rely so much on case law but there is nothing quite like statutory clout to improve an organisations powers of persuasion massie gives an example of a restaurant that refused entry to a blind person because of their guide dog instead text: once it was the province of the worried parent to protect the young from the gruesome lyrics of modern musicians but now the role seems to have been taken over by the students union leaders of sheffield universitys union have enraged members by slapping a censorious ban on the controversial rapper eminem the union banned the controversial american from club nights and student media after a handful of members complained about his lyrics on bludgeoning women and gays to death and abusing his stinkin ass mom the union ruled that steel press sheffields awardwinning student newspaper was allowed to write straight news stories mentioning the singer but not to review his latest cd the marshall mathers lp or his uk tour which starts next week fans have been barred from wearing eminem tshirts in the bar but students said it constituted censorship and they would break the ban dan morfitt head of music at sure the student radio station said the ban was extreme and he planned to break it on monday by playing an eminem record to see what happened we have really got to go for it to break this ban of course we are against homophobia but were all over and are unlikely to be turned into bigots by a couple of lines in a song he said the nationwide student broadcast network based in london was played in breaks on sures frequency and it would continue to play eminem jan webster editor of steel press which today publishes an editorial on the ban complaining of censorship and the nanny state said three out of students complained we despise homophobia but i am worried about political correctness when it becomes an issue of control by a small minority david whitley a third year student journalist said they are banning eminem from being reviewed but the university is still allowed to sell his records in the shop so homophobia is ok by them if they can make a profit by it a spokeswoman for sheffield students union said the shop should not be selling eminem she also said a referendum had been taken among students andreaz nowakowski of the sheffield union said our aim is to create a culture of tolerance equality and respect for all our members eminems homophobia and misogynism spoiled that atmosphere mr nowakowski said the fact that students yesterday staged protests at the ban was frustrating but they would be given a chance to air their views the campaign for press and broadcasting freedom called the ban heavyhanded censorship but the national union of students and gay rights groups welcomed it owain james national nus president said nus will not condone sexist or homophobic language in any way angela mason executive director of stonewall the gay rights group said public debate on eminem was needed peter tatchell of outrage said the group was against rally against hate outside the grammy awards ceremony in los angeles on february where eminem is expected to sing and collect awards not welcome from pepsi to straw jack straw in february last year text: women are adopting macho working patterns and sacrificing family lives in order to get ahead despite moves to make the workplace more familyfriendly psychologists said yesterday although the government is increasing statutory maternity leave and many employers have polices which should allow women to achieve a better worklife balance many women still feel they must conform to the male way of working across the corporate spectrum successful women are working long hours and taking short maternity leaves researchers janet smithson of manchester metropolitan university elizabeth stokoe of university college worcester and chris coupland of birmingham university looked at women working in banking retail and accountancy women managers tend to talk about themselves in male terms im still my own man etc and they feel they have to keep up with the hours men work network alongside them and take as little leave there were some women who took only two weeks off after having a baby said ms smithson the researchers found that the concept of flexible hours was a myth women were expected to arrive early leave late and go for a drink after work with their colleagues or face slipping down the career ladder other research unveiled at the british psychological societys conference revealed that women were generally disadvantaged in interviews but still managed to perform better than men jo silvester of city university london looked at the graduate recruitment programme of a petrochemical company she discovered that men were generally allowed to talk for longer in interviews and were asked openended questions which allow for lengthy responses women on the other hand were asked closed questions and were not given so long too talk despite this they performed better in facetoface interviews than men although women were being asked more closed questions than men they were presenting themselves better and they were more in control said dr silvester

text: the government was yesterday urged to go further to close the pay gap between men and women as it unveiled plans to rely on exhortation rather than legislation to persuade employers to pay fairly campaigners questioned the decision to rule out legislation to compel firms to review their pay structures to root out inequalities in favour of a voluntary system twentyfive years after the passing of the equal pay act the government yesterday set out measures intended to help close the pay gap which still means women fulltime workers on average earn four fifths of mens wages the employment minister tessa jowell announced the creation of fair pay champions including trade unionists and business leaders who will promote pay equality she also unveiled plans for annual awards for employers who conduct and act on pay reviews however while equality campaigners praised government efforts to highlight the continuing pay gap they warned that new legislation was needed to address bad employers who continue to flout pay laws maryann stephenson director of the womens rights pressure group the fawcett society said there is no reason not to introduce compulsory pay audits now the reason we the trades unions and the equal opportunities commission have been calling for legislation is that companies have not been doing pay reviews under a voluntary system in a report published last month the eocs equal pay task force called for compulsory audits saying no real progress could be made without them the government opted for a voluntary approach wary of prompting a backlash from business over excess regulation business groups including the cbi which has fiercely resisted compulsory audits yesterday welcomed the an nouncement john cridland cbi deputy director general said this is a good set of proposals for tackling the gender pay gap which should be both workable for business and effective for women in the workplace ms jowell yesterday told an industrial society conference that women were still losing out in the labour market having less responsibility lower pay and fewer promotion opportunities than men

text: its so cold on the streets and so frightening says marie a yearold student who ran away from a birmingham care home just before she was she felt that she had no choice but to run away because the stepfather who had sexually abused her as a child which led to her going into care in the first place kept following her he would appear and sit next to her as she sat on the bus to school and hang around the care home when i was he was jailed for the abuse for a while but it was all over the papers and everyone knew what he had done to me she says in the end i couldnt stand it and felt the only thing i could do was run away she finished her gcses took a job washing up in a restaurant for three weeks to save enough money for a train ticket to london and then ran the worst thing was that no one would listen to me she recalls i was scared and nervous when i got on the train but i felt i couldnt go back to the situation i had left behind kids will only run away if the situation they are in is so bad that living on the streets seems like a better option something has got to be really wrong to make a young person do a thing like that marie was so terrified when she arrived at euston station that she simply walked the streets for three days too frightened of what might happen if she lay down and closed her eyes i felt so alone in the world she says nobody in my care home bothered to report me missing the streets are full of homeless young people crying out for love marie was one of an estimated young people who run away each year the commonest reasons for children taking flight include desperation at not being listened to rows with parents over the amount of freedom they are allowed bullying at school and drug problems or abuse at home a new paper from the social exclusion unit consultation on young runaways highlights the problem and puts a variety of solutions to the problem out to consultation by the age of one in nine children will have run away for at least one night with a quarter of those ending up sleeping rough some have to survive through begging stealing or prostitution and many are sexually abused on the streets while children like marie who have been in care make up a large proportion of runaways approximately four in the report finds that are fleeing stepfamilies and oneparent families compared to who live with both birth parents but contrary to stereotype poverty was found not to be a significant factor leading to young people running away those from leafy suburbs are just as likely to flee as those from deprived innercity areas the majority of runaways are aged between and and are more likely to be girls than boys although boys tend to run away earlier and more often it is not only a problem of troubled adolescence an estimated children under also run away each year of whom about a third are under eight shockingly a further children a year are thrown out by their parents the report also notes that the longer runaways are away the more vulnerable they become there is no national network of services in place so emergency organisations like childline find it very hard to refer children who phone in a crisis to appropriate local services the report proposes a series of measures both to prevent young people from running away in the first place and to provide decent support services when they do plans include an interview for each young person who has run away to identify the reasons for fleeing and to try to tackle them rather than just dumping the children back in the situation from which they have fled a network of refuges so that young people are not forced to live rough and the establishment of a named person in each area to coordinate services for runaways chris now ran away from numerous care placements about times he believes that refuges are essential but also that fundamental changes in the care system are necessary i was frightened on the streets he recalls but i also felt free i shoplifted to survive i received no support in care nobody listened and i was bullied for me living on the streets was better than that much of the data in the governments new report comes from research carried out by the childrens society which has been working with young runaways for the past years the charitys penny dean welcomed the report but is urging the government to implement some of the proposals such as providing children with interviews right away rather than await the outcome of the threemonth consultation process a social exclusion unit spokesman has responded that this would not be possible i really hope the government wont delay over this says dean young runaways are a very hard to reach group who need a lot of support a lot of these young people view statutory agencies with mistrust and we need a mechanism to draw together expertise from the voluntary sector to deliver the services young people want she condemns the lack of funding for refuges centrepoint in london is the only one in britain and argues that although the concept of childrens refuges was established in the children act the money to run them has not been forthcoming from the government without such refuges there is no safety net to protect children from the dangers of the streets besides the government recommendations the childrens society is calling for more early intervention to prevent running away support and mediation for parents and children where families have divorced separated or reformed and more ethnically sensitive services dorit braun of parentline plus expresses concern about the number of children who run away from stepfamilies jealousy of a parents new partner can fuel conflict between children and adults in stepfamilies she says many children do adjust well but a small minority dont the young people and the adults in a stepfamily need to be given time to understand each other the dynamics of a stepfamily are much more complex than those in an intact family and stepparents can be viewed by children as interfering and making a difficult situation worse the government has highlighted a small project in gloucester called astra alternative solutions to running away which employs just three parttime workers as a model of good practice the project works with young people who have run away to prevent recurrences staff listen to young peoples concerns and then try to work with them their parents and other agencies such as schools and social services to find solutions with which both the young people and their parents or carers are happy police estimate that the project has reduced the number of repeat runaways by one former runaway sally says the project has helped her resolve a difficult situation with her mother my mum didnt like my friends the way i dressed or the fact that i wore makeup and she didnt like me going out one day i just didnt go home from school i was scared because i didnt know where i could go in the end i stayed at a friends house astra talked to my mum and talked to me now she gives me a bit more freedom i understand her better and she understands me better now that marie is settled in london studying for a university degree and living in a flat that a childrens societysupported tenancy project helped to secure for her the days of trudging around the capitals west end with nowhere to go seem very far off i love my home she says ive got my own front room my own bedroom a cat friends and a normal life i dont ever want to go through what i went through again and if young people text: suddenly a crucial issue is back on the agenda equal pay an equal opportunities commission eoc taskforce reported last month yesterday the employment minister tessa jowell responded by announcing a pay audit of every government department and agency with each being required to draw up plans to close the pay gap she set out plans for the appointment of fair pay champions from the business and trade union world to promote pay equality and confirmed there would be annual castle awards named after barbara castle who steered the equal pay act through the commons for employers who have made major progress towards closing the gap what more some may ask could women want quite a lot yesterdays package falls pathetically short of what is needed as the eoc report confirmed the uk has the worst record in europe on equal pay a gap of between the earnings of men and women it calculated that between one quarter and one half of this gap was a direct cause of discrimination the rest being caused by occupational segregation of women workers being in the lowest pay categories like catering retail and cleaning and a high concentration in parttime work the act has achieved progress a narrowing of the pay gap from in to and an increase from one third to one half of working age women in employment yet at all levels of society unequal pay perniciously persists millions of women who carry just as much responsibility as male counterparts are being paid much less business was given years to correct this unacceptable practice but failed the eoc was right to insist that employers should be required to carry out mandatory pay audits and ministers were wrong to reject it of course there are good employers but there is also a hardcore of hardliners who will not be moved by exhortations to carry out voluntary audits the public service one of the worst offenders should have been ordered to follow the eoc line it took a year fight through the european court before speech therapists forced the nhs to put things right other groups are still awaiting justice once again ministers have been too eager to secure the business vote this was political madness women voters have far more clout they might even decide to use it

text: its so cold on the streets and so frightening says marie a yearold student who ran away from a birmingham care home just before she was she felt that she had no choice but to run away because the stepfather who had sexually abused her as a child which led to her going into care in the first place kept following her he would appear and sit next to her as she sat on the bus to school and hang around the care home when i was he was jailed for the abuse for a while but it was all over the papers and everyone knew what he had done to me she says in the end i couldnt stand it and felt the only thing i could do was run away she finished her gcses took a job washing up in a restaurant for three weeks to save enough money for a train ticket to london and then ran the worst thing was that no one would listen to me she recalls i was scared and nervous when i got on the train but i felt i couldnt go back to the situation i had left behind kids will only run away if the situation they are in is so bad that living on the streets seems like a better option something has got to be really wrong to make a young person do a thing like that marie was so terrified when she arrived at euston station that she simply walked the streets for three days too frightened of what might happen if she lay down and closed her eyes i felt so alone in the world she says nobody in my care home bothered to report me missing the streets are full of homeless young people crying out for love marie was one of an estimated young people who run away each year the commonest reasons for children taking flight include desperation at not being listened to rows with parents over the amount of freedom they are allowed bullying at school and drug problems or abuse at home a new paper from the social exclusion unit consultation on young runaways highlights the problem and puts a variety of solutions to the problem out to consultation by the age of one in nine children will have run away for at least one night with a quarter of those ending up sleeping rough some have to survive through begging stealing or prostitution and many are sexually abused on the streets while children like marie who have been in care make up a large proportion of runaways approximately four in the report finds that are fleeing stepfamilies and oneparent families compared to who live with both birth parents but contrary to stereotype poverty was found not to be a significant factor leading to young people running away those from leafy suburbs are just as likely to flee as those from deprived innercity areas the majority of runaways are aged between and and are more likely to be girls than boys although boys tend to run away earlier and more often it is not only a problem of troubled adolescence an estimated children under also run away each year of whom about a third are under eight shockingly a further children a year are thrown out by their parents the report also notes that the longer runaways are away the more vulnerable they become there is no national network of services in place so emergency organisations like childline find it very hard to refer children who phone in a crisis to appropriate local services the report proposes a series of measures both to prevent young people from running away in the first place and to provide decent support services when they do plans include an interview for each young person who has run away to identify the reasons for fleeing and to try to tackle them rather than just dumping the children back in the situation from which they have fled a network of refuges so that young people are not forced to live rough and the establishment of a named person in each area to coordinate services for runaways chris now ran away from numerous care placements about times he believes that refuges are essential but also that fundamental changes in the care system are necessary i was frightened on the streets he recalls but i also felt free i shoplifted to survive i received no support in care nobody listened and i was bullied for me living on the streets was better than that much of the data in the governments new report comes from research carried out by the childrens society which has been working with young runaways for the past years the charitys penny dean welcomed the report but is urging the government to implement some of the proposals such as providing children with interviews right away rather than await the outcome of the threemonth consultation process a social exclusion unit spokesman has responded that this would not be possible i really hope the government wont delay over this says dean young runaways are a very hard to reach group who need a lot of support a lot of these young people view statutory agencies with mistrust and we need a mechanism to draw together expertise from the voluntary sector to deliver the services young people want she condemns the lack of funding for refuges centrepoint in london is the only one in britain and argues that although the concept of childrens refuges was established in the children act the money to run them has not been forthcoming from the government without such refuges there is no safety net to protect children from the dangers of the streets besides the government recommendations the childrens society is calling for more early intervention to prevent running away support and mediation for parents and children where families have divorced separated or reformed and more ethnically sensitive services dorit braun of parentline plus expresses concern about the number of children who run away from stepfamilies jealousy of a parents new partner can fuel conflict between children and adults in stepfamilies she says many children do adjust well but a small minority dont the young people and the adults in a stepfamily need to be given time to understand each other the dynamics of a stepfamily are much more complex than those in an intact family and stepparents can be viewed by children as interfering and making a difficult situation worse the government has highlighted a small project in gloucester called astra alternative solutions to running away which employs just three parttime workers as a model of good practice the project works with young people who have run away to prevent recurrences staff listen to young peoples concerns and then try to work with them their parents and other agencies such as schools and social services to find solutions with which both the young people and their parents or carers are happy police estimate that the project has reduced the number of repeat runaways by one former runaway sally says the project has helped her resolve a difficult situation with her mother my mum didnt like my friends the way i dressed or the fact that i wore makeup and she didnt like me going out one day i just didnt go home from school i was scared because i didnt know where i could go in the end i stayed at a friends house astra talked to my mum and talked to me now she gives me a bit more freedom i understand her better and she understands me better now that marie is settled in london studying for a university degree and living in a flat that a childrens societysupported tenancy project helped to secure for her the days of trudging around the capitals west end with nowhere to go seem very far off i love my home she says ive got my own front room my own bedroom a cat friends and a normal life i dont ever want to go through what i went through again and if young people like me had more rights they wouldnt have to either

text: the coincidence of the two events could not have been more poignant last thursday morning the prime minister launched a new drive to protect runaway children in the afternoon a team of child specialists who had run the children societys refuge for runaways in leeds met for a farewell party following its closure late last year where once there were four refuges for such children now there is only one centrepoint in london the stark statistics in last weeks report from the social exclusion unit seu set out the dimensions and the risks by the age of one in nine children has run away for a night most find a temporary home with family or friends but sleep rough suffer physical harm and sexual assault one in ends up surviving through begging stealing drug dealing or prostitution runaways as exasperated charity workers have noted are everybodys concern but nobodys responsibility they fall through the welfare net crossing geographical as well as service boundaries but now a national strategy with downing streets backing is promised there is delight at the childrens society which has campaigned on the issue for years but will the new consultation process still further delay developments which ought to be happening now we do need a national network of services for runaways but we need a preventive strategy too four out of five run because of problems at home parental conflict physical or sexual abuse most want to go back but with the conflict resolved childline can help but it needs more childcentred agencies to which it can refer callers wider provision of school support mentors peer groups counsellors is one front more child advocates and family mediators are other options we need more flexible safe places refuges yes but they are incredibly expensive emergency foster homes and even bampb with foster carers could help postrunaway services can stop repeat runners these include family group conferences mediation plus independent interviews by child advocates whitehall also needs to look at why we have had to wait so long the initial refuges were set up by bending the law technically the childrens society could have been prosecuted for harbouring runaways this was changed by the children act but still no statutory refuges emerged nor state funds for charitable refuges state agencies did not refer the children ipso facto no state money it was absurd they were unsustainable without state aid children continued to turn to them only when the last two announced closure was one saved as tony blair noted we must find a better way

text: heard the one about the female secretary who slept with her boss and hey presto she was promoted the truth is that its men who are more likely to sleep with their superiors to secure promotion at work according to a new survey by online recruitment agency planetrecruit of the men questioned said they would have sex with their boss if it would get them a higherstatus job while less than a third of the women said they would do so the survey which reveals the lengths office workers will go to get ahead at work also found that of men said they would be happy to resort to character assassination to secure better jobs whereas only of women said they would whats more twice as many men as women were happy to take credit for some one elses work this doesnt mean that women are less manipulative however far more women than men claims the report are prepared to moan to win the bosss sympathy vote the report shows very clearly that women feel more comfortable employing less obvious or more underhand career enhancing tactics than men says its author megan hayes if shes found to have done something wrong at work shell play the oh but things are so hard at home card or shell keep making comments about how shes not being challenged enough in her environment in the hope of getting a better job says hayes nevertheless as other research shows women are more likely than men to shoot themselves in the foot when offered the chance to prove theyre ready for promotion our study found that women are far more likely than men to underrate their own performance at work this could be one of the reasons that women find it harder than men to get promoted says haihai yuan coauthor and researcher at gallup organisation the chief reason that more women than men are willing to devalue themselves is because of lack of confidence in their own abilities found the report this comes as no surprise to debra allcock author of high flying who trains women to be more assertive at all levels of organisations typically they tend to measure themselves in terms of what they cannot do rather than what they can as a result they think that they are less deserving not necessarily than men are but than any other employee it doesnt help that women are more likely than men to take criticism as a sign that theyre inadequate says anne dickson author of women at work the stereotypical accusation that women cannot handle criticism at work and take it too personally is partly true she says the ability to respond to criticism without being wounded is easily undermined by our need for approval whether secretaries are male or female theres a growing body of advice on the best ways to ensure promotion exposure showing the right people how hard you are working and networking are increasingly crucial says beverley stone a corporate psychologist its about letting the right people know what you are doing what your plans are and that youre doing well she says after all in todays office there are more managers than ever who have a say in promoting secretaries fiona elsa specialist in training and development at ashridge management college believes that its worth asking as early as possible if a promotion route is mapped out for you if so ask to see your development plan if not ask how else you can best move up the ladder it will show your employer that youre keen to give your best to the company the best time to ask about promotion is at your annual performance appraisal max a eggert an appraisal specialist says secretarial staff are at a particular advantage when it comes to getting the best from appraisals most occur annually he says but throughout the year there should really be onetoones which are essentially mini appraisals ensuring that no progress is missed since secretaries are usually in charge of their managers diary they can just book in a halfhour slot once a month or so if youre turned down for what you think is a deserved promotion always ask why ask too what you can do to improve your chances next time round if the improvements mean training is required suggest a date to start it no ambitious secretary will hang around in a post where theres no chance of development and your employers will know that

text: when teresa gorman stands down at the election her yellow jacket aimed to catch the speakers eye will be missed so will her double function as the sand in the parliamentary oyster as a radical feminist and hard right tory europhobe i never thought i mourn her passing after our first confrontation when i uncovered the fact that she had taken years off her age in to inherit in the safe tory seat of billericay from harvey proctor maligned as a whipper of rent boys when i flourished her birth and marriage certificates which showed she was not as she had claimed to her selection conference mrs gorman said its a fair cop her selectors gullibility was understandable she showed the effectiveness of hormone replacement therapy of which she is a prime defender as st teresa of the menopause even as she departs at her skin appearance and behaviour are those of a much younger woman the saddest thing about her departure is the manner of it in she was suspended for a month for misleading the commons standards and privileges committee about properties owned some overseas by her husband and herself she hated this sort of fussy poking into her affairs because she has always been an extreme whip to want to exile her to the falklands in she deserted john redwood as a badmannered insensitive snob whose remarks on single mothers were a disaster dismissed william hague as a willie and voted text: equal pay tsars will shame sexist employers into giving women a fair wage under a government action plan to root out workplace discrimination ministers will stage an annual summit to review the progress made for working women at which poor performers will be expected to explain why they pay their female workers less than males meanwhile leading figures from the arts trade unions and business will be appointed as fair pay champions within their industries however employment minister tessa jowell who is to unveil the package on tuesday is likely to come under fire from equal opportunities watchdogs for rejecting their demands for mandatory pay audits or for a change in the law the equal opportunities commission wants employers to be forced to review the salaries of all staff and publish findings exposing any discrimination but ministers have rejected the idea which risks antagonising the business lobby arguing that the pay gap is not only caused by sexism but also by women choosing or being steered into lowpaid and lowskilled jobs jowell will say these are practical problems requiring practical solutions not more legislation an per cent pay gap is totally unacceptable even an per cent pay gap is totally unacceptable any pay gap driven by discrimination is totally unacceptable she will say the government will be working in partnership with business and the trade unions to make sure that the next ten years will be a decade for women in work a decade in which the employment opportunities for all women will improve and in which the unfair unacceptable and unlawful pay gap will be closed women currently earn only per cent of mens rates for equivalent work although the gap has closed since when women on average earned p for every pound taken home by a man in the same job experts argue that years of antisex discrimination laws have failed to close it and that more drastic action is needed recent research by the womens unit in whitehall exploded the myth that women earn less simply because they have family responsibilities showing that even childless females can expect to earn more than less than men in the same jobs over their lifetimes jowells plan will focus on parttime workers for whom the gap in hourly pay is even wider and women returning to work after having children new mothers on average see their hourly pay fall by up to per cent when they go back partly because employers may assume they are no longer as committed to careers and partly because many go back to slightly different jobs the network of pay champions will spearhead a public campaign making it unacceptable to give women workers a poorer deal jowell will organise a yearly summit the first of which is expected later this year for business and the unions at which text: who believes in equality even the communists were more preoccupied with the dictatorship of the proletariat than achieving genuine equality most liberals content themselves with the ronald dworkin proposition that their obligation is to argue for a government that will redistribute rather than do anything themselves this is a value that few beyond the monastery are prepared to live out this lack of belief in equality is starkly exposed by what has happened to women in the years since the sex discrimination and equal pay acts became law sadly not much as this weeks white paper on equal opportunities will doubtless declare the bald fact remains on average women earn per cent less than men worse as a rash of recent employment tribunal judgments has exposed sexist attitudes and intimidatory and harassing behaviour are still rampant in the workplace the accounts especially from the city should make even the most committed convert to the belief that girls are on top pause widespread talk of dogs and slappers taunts about why womens relationships might be going wrong their being passed over for promotion the casual assumption that their prime purpose is to be slept with their being ignored at meetings this is not a portrait of sexual equality but of pernicious discrimination against this background worries about men and their psychological problems about adjusting to a new environment in which women win all the prizes are laughable men have plenty of problems and it is true that conceptions of being the warriorprovider are dying but that doesnt mean that it has ceased to be a mans world its become a mans world in a different way men dominate the old institutions of power ranging from the judiciary to the boardroom and they dominate the new institutions of power ranging from the media to the informal networks of the ict revolution during the last couple of months ive attended two weekend conferences at one with some attending there were no women at the other of some journalists there were only two the old feminist charge that the informal networking and informationgathering options open to men are in a different league from those available to women seems never more true what is shocking is that so much of this is accepted without public protest too many women take the view that if they kick up a fuss they might damage their career and that their best approach is simply to be very good at what they do and be one of the boys results should speak for themselves the trouble is that results dont count as much as they should and being one of the boys validates attitudes that should have gone out with the ark given the tradeoffs obstacles and deep cultural perhaps even biological imprinting of women its difficult to criticise or complain about any individual womans choice but we all end up losers work is impoverished by gender stereotyping the lack of a critical mass of senior women from whom the next generation of organisational leaders can be recruited means that the poverty of womens representation becomes selfsustaining poor pay and inadequate promotion while at a junior level the male temptation to see their female colleagues as sisters of the lapdancers they pay to ogle is not counteracted some tough nettles have to be grasped the structured inequality women confront is so entwined with male attitudes towards the erotic and sexual that instruments like the sex discrimination act seem puny at its rawest both sexes expect women to be the prime carer of children and for the erotic to depend on women pleasing men out of this maelstrom comes sys temic economic and social inequality it isnt as bad as it was both sexes are learning that equality is a better route to mutual sexual pleasure than inequality and this must surely ultimately cascade into more equal economic and social relationships but before that can happen the next massive bar is motherhood as my colleague at the industrial society richard reeves argues in his pamphlet mothers versus men it is a taboo to state the obvious as long as women take the prime responsibility for bringing up children then it is rational for employers to pay this group of workers at a discount because they take more time off work and sometimes when their child is ill at inconvenient and unpredictable moments it is only when parenting is equally shared and is an equally unpredictable cost to both men and women that the rational calculus will change in the meantime it is hardly a surprise that most women chief executives and directors are childless the prime barrier is the view that warriorprovider men and nestbuilding women are incapable of sharing parenting if this is true ive come round to the opinion that we might as well give up on other battles over equality in last weeks special observer magazine britain uncovered tim adams argued that the growing realisation that we are now living in close proximity to so much incredible wealth has become psychologically destabilising our ordinariness becomes a source of disaffection and we want to do something dramatic to interrupt the pattern of our lives the scale of inequality in income and wealth pollutes our capacity to be at ease with ourselves i think adams is right but there is little possibility of assembling a political coalition to do anything unless we take the case for more equality more seriously but that seems improbable if we cannot crack sexual inequality as conservative newspapers know without being told every headline asserting that working mothers never working parents damage their children in some way is another blow against the progressive argument in its totality you make women guilty entrench sexual inequality and hold back the wider case for more equality which is why the old aphorism that the personal is political is as true as ever but for personal interventions to work you need a legislative and cultural framework to support you in that sense next weeks white paper is an important moment its taken four years but at least the government is offering a signal that sexual equality matters the big question is whether enough men are prepared to listen and change
