text: professional women are for the first time making up the majority of volunteers overseas but rarely get the opportunity of a foreign posting in their regular careers according to an investigation of gender prejudice by the international development charity vso it found the number of women volunteers signing up for service abroad has trebled over years reflecting womens higher qualifications and changing patterns of family life last year vso had women working abroad and men but women took only of international assignments in companies that commonly regarded overseas experience as a key factor in deciding promotion according to research for vso by hilary harris director of research at cranfield universitys school of management she said the vso experience exploded myths about women that were damaging their career prospects by denying them the chance to work abroad there are three very potent assumptions first that women are not interested in posts abroad second that family ties prevent them accepting posts abroad and finally that women sent on overseas assignments are doomed to fail in the face of prejudice in certain countries yet the vso figures offer evidence not only that women are interested in challenging postings overseas but that they thrive when given the opportunity to do so she said we have to ask by denying women such experience have we created a new glass ceiling women make up of middle management but represent just of all chief executive officers an nop poll commissioned by vso found of women would like the chance to work overseas but more than of women and men thought it was harder for women to gain respect in some foreign cultures more than of women and men said it was difficult for women to take up posts abroad because of family commitments and nearly half said it was harder for women to work abroad than men vso said these public attitudes contrasted sharply with the evidence of its returning women volunteers most of the women volunteers were in their twenties and fifties the older volunteers said they were prompted by freedom from family ties an urge to see the world and travel with a purpose the younger volunteers saw vso as a boost to career prospects and said they were attracted by the sense of adventure ruth lewis the charitys director of recruitment said here is evidence of a pool of female talent and ability waiting to be tapped not just by vso but by the wider business community

text: if genius is the capacity for taking infinite pains then michael martin the first catholic speaker since the reformation is a genius despite sneers about his lowly glasgow origins and accent with two years of hard slog in the tearoom and some highly skilled tactical planning mr martin outclassed a dozen others the contest for the speaker his planning was illustrated by an incident in january when the first story emerged that betty boothroyd was thinking of standing down a group of labour mps were in australia on a parliamentary visit when one pretended that he would stand as a drastic reformer all but one of his colleagues promised to support him the exception said he could not back him because he was already part of mick martins campaign team this long planned campaign had tactical brilliance from the start mr martin recognised his own weakness as an orthodox rather oldfashioned roman catholic opposed to abortion and to lowering the age of consent for homosexuals he had been one of only six labour mps to voted against legalising homosexual sex at these two stands put him against new young women labour mps who universally backed both reforms two years ago he set about neutralising all these expected antagonisms by working the tearoom this meant cultivating new young women mps who would otherwise disagree with them helping in his genial fatherly way to solve their problems as new mps and congratulating them in handwritten letters on their maiden speeches when the speakership election finally took place in october not only was he flanked by young women mps on either side but he was nominated by ann keen the icon of the gay sex at brigade for having led the crusade the upshot of mr martins twoyear campaign was that he defeated all his opponents including the highlyqualified one nation tory sir george young for whom tony blair indicated his preference and for whom commons leader margaret becket parliamentary labour party chairman clive soley and dozens of other labour mps voted mr martin to beat this highly articulate old etonian by to virtually all the tory mps abstained from the final vote to endorse him with eight even voting against him although this risked being ignored when in the future they wanted to catch his eye and speak in debates their hostility was an expression of classbased detestation towards glaswegian machine politics this was echoed by journalists who recalled his role in barring hacks unaccompanied by mps from the commons riverside terrace an attractive place on warm summer evenings michael martin emerged from the lost generation of labour mps so tagged by former prime minister james callaghan who were elected in just as the tories took over for years he represents springburn the safest labour seat in glasgow with among the highest concentration of council housing in britain its inhabitants are mostly poorlypaid and the number of its unemployed is among glasgows highest mr martin shared his constituents background his father was a merchant navy stoker his ship was torpedoed three times during the war his mother a school cleaner had to bring up five children on her own after her husbands death mr martin himself had to leave st patricks boys school at to start an apprenticeship at a local trainrepairing workshop he moved on to become a sheetmetal worker at rolls royce aero engines becoming an auew shop steward it was as a union organiser for nupe that he got into his political stride in congratulating him on his election as the speaker charles kennedy leader of the lib dems recalled when mr martin had organised a very welcome nupe strike at young charless school in mr martin was elected to glasgow corporation and to glasgow district council the next year in he was selected to replace richard buchanan as the candidate for springburn once in the commons the closest he got to power was as parliamentary private secretary to denis healey in he failed to shine as a parliamentary orator and was never promoted to labours front bench instead he made his way up the parliamentary ladder dutifully serving on committees he earned brownie points as chairman of the administration committee organising childcare vouchers for the commons staff after serving for years on the chairmens panel he became deputy speaker in this whetted his appetite for the top job as speaker he has started by being tough cutting short wordy mps if they cannot formulate an intelligent question within a minute he even invited one tory john butterfill to leave the chamber when he challenged the speaker privately for not calling him in a debate on the middle east genial but with claws he lacks speaker boothroyds showgirl charm ask aristotle about michael martin

text: there was a game they used to play at the bank where sue temple worked every morning when she walked in her male colleagues would try to guess what underwear she had on camisole they would yell or french knickers one of women brokers among men she would pass the bank of desks while its occupants crouched and craned to verify their guesses it was like a building site she says only all the blokes were wearing suits the gap between modern standards of behaviour and those practised in the city widened again last week when the japanese finance house nomura paid out to isabelle terrillon one of its former brokers terrillon returned from maternity leave three years ago to find that her job no longer existed at a tribunal in stratford east london she described nomura as the kind of place in which a male colleague would declare loudly enough for her to hear that of all the women on the dealing floor the one he really wanted to fuck was isabelle during a client meeting terrillon said she was asked to strip down and administer a massage to one of her colleagues if she showed displeasure she was asked whether or not she was going to start crying last monday she dropped the sexual discrimination claim and accepted a outofcourt settlement for unfair dismissal behaviour in the city is traditionally graded between the extremes of yobbish brokerage and genteel corporate finance brokerage it is imagined is a gladiatorial arena in which everyone is mean to everyone else while corporate finance is a euphemism for gentlemanly according to women who have worked in both however it is not the degree of sexism that differs so much as its expression which by subtle means is as alive now as it was during the s over the past five years the equal opportunities commission has taken on cases of sex discrimination from workers in the city six of which have been successful many of them settle before they get to court says a spokeswoman who believes that these figures are a drop in the ocean most city males think the world is divided into three types of women says one former analyst the sweet virginal julia roberts lookalike who responds with delighted giggles to any sort of perfectly normal workplace banter yet is desperate to don crotchless knickers and give the boss a blowjob then there are the mothers unreliable because not only did they go and get pregnant but they have the nerve to clock off early if a child breaks an arm and then there is the largest group of women the humourless bitches for years helen cartwright was a money broker for an international swiss bank one of six women among men she earned a year it was like a cartoon she says the men in the office would say when are you going to go home get married and have babies the more they put me down the better they were regarded by the others on the off chance that they would get lucky cartwrights male colleagues would book rooms by the hour at london hotels such as the strand palace or the great eastern hotel and try to persuade her to return there with them on one occasion a male colleague approached cartwrights desk undid his flies and exposed the stitches of his recent circumcision to her she told him to put it away or she would hit it with the phone the nastiest thing they ever did was when i split up with my exhusband they talked very loudly about the new girl he was seeing it was devastating i lost a stone and a half in two weeks cartwright eventually left the bank and received an outofcourt settlement on the condition that she never disclosed its value these were not the sort of circumstances into which laura browning imagined she was entering after leaving a relatively civilised us company she joined a more traditional british merchant bank as a middleranking executive if id had a tape recorder i could have taken them to the cleaners she says i had a very swashbuckling client who required long meetings late into the night and at weekends during one meeting this man cleared a boardroom of people by saying could all of you please leave while i speak to linda once they had left he actually chased me round the boardroom it was unbelievable part of me wanted to laugh the other to slap him when the client persisted in commenting on daviess clothes and tried to grab her again she took the matter to a senior director my dear he said did no one ever tell you the customer is always right the subtext says davies was that if the client wanted to sleep with her then she should let him i went straight to a headhunter and said get me out of here this kind of overt grappling has been replaced recently by more covert forms of intimidation much favoured by litigationweary bankers it is about the subtle discounting of ability says helena dennison chair of the city womens network which represents senior female executives working in the square mile covert discrimination means rubbishing a womans contribution during meetings either with snide remarks or remarks about her appearance covert discrimination undermines confidence the language of sexism grows more respectable the further up a company you go becomes more subtle commons magazine he scorns miss jobsworth southeast who asks the prime minister patsy questions from the floor if the blair babe manages to stagger to the end of the sentence which the whips have thrust in her hands its a minor miracle infuriated by this constant slur fiona mactaggart mp did a survey and found no evidence that women ask more patsy questions than men but in that beligerent chamber on wednesday afternoons the sketch writers snooze through the plentiful mens sycophantic and inept questions waking to sharpen their pens only for the bright jackets of the women women are funny at the end of four years have the women occupying of the labour benches made a difference two new academic studies tell the story one says in contrast to the view that new labour women mps have failed women women mps have made a considerable difference acting for women within and beyond parliament the other analyses their voting record and its findings will please the mocking press gallery first the bald facts paul cowley of hull university studying the figures finds that women mps of the intake were indeed obedient at first they were seven times less likely to rebel than male mps of the same intake as time went on they got a bit braver but were still twice as unlikely to rebel as the men does that make them craven lobbyfodder and a general waste of benchspace that depends on what you think mps are for is rebellion against your own party the emblem of backbench effectiveness voting against your own party is one way to claim political virility and independence but it doesnt get results fiona mactaggart wrote in her fabian pamphlet rebellion is always rare most mps would fail if rebellion was the test all the same the women mps behave differently why at they never formed a critical mass in the house of commons oddities still not the norm most complain bitterly of the thundering maleness of the place and its traditions the chamber is the part of the job most of them like least the grandstanding strutting bellowing they are less likely to judge their own effectiveness in terms of their theatrical performance confrontation seems to them an unproductive avenue to changing policy women in parliaments around the world tend to follow the same pattern of voting loyalty they do politics differently and perhaps better dr sarah childs of middlesex university in an academic study out shortly in parliamentary affairs probes beyond the bare voting statistics she interviewed new women mps shortly after their arrival in westminster in and again four years later and text: yvette cooper is a golden girl both as labours youngest minister and for her connections married to gordon browns top adviserconfidante ed balls she had worked for bill clinton and john smith and was seen as so talented that sir geoffrey lofthouse was prised out of safe pontefract and castleford to give her an easy entry to the commons in labour terms she has the advantage of a grandfather who was a miner and a father tony cooper who has been the general secretary of the engineers and managers association born in inverness in she went from eggars comprehensive and alton sixth form college in hampshire to balliol college oxford where she tried cannabis and collected a first class degree in ppe she then went on to harvard university as a kennedy scholar and the london school of economics where she collared a masters in economics elected in at the age of she went on to the select committees on education and employment as well as intelligence and security she turned down the offer to become a parliamentary private secretary and in was named under secretary for public health at the youngest in ministerial office she juggles her ministerial role and the family demands of a treasurybased husband and a twoyearold daughter ellie by spending midweek at her kennington flat with weekends in her yorkshire constituency she lives up to her highlyorganised reputation her main problem has been to live up to her high promise as a junior minister when the main decisions and publicity radiate from its top man health secretary alan milburn in her commons sessions replies her elfin little girl appearance and high pitched voice do not lend weight and her earnest intensity is not often softened by humour as a former journalist at the independent she does better in articles than in the commons in urging better diets for the nations children she can be over eager and caused sir john krebs to tell her get your tanks off my lawn after she had twice revealed details from his food standards agency without his permission she made her biggest impact in july by launching a report showing labour had failed to ease persistent class inequalities she said daughters of unskilled men born in were an astonishing nine times more likely to become a teenage mother than girls whose fathers were more highly qualified she also made headlines after disclosing that more hiv infections come from heterosexuals than homosexuals other blair babes envious of her early promotion think she doesnt dress well enough for the job tagging her miss selfridge but she and her husband are still rated to become the next labour generations golden couple ask aristotle about yvette cooper

text: frank furedi is not a relaxed parent he can be laidback about some things his fiveyearold son jacob is encouraged to play in the woods near their family home and furedi hopes he will soon be able to cycle to school but when it comes to illness furedi frets he worries about his sons health he can even quote you jacobs temperature when he was last poorly in short he is paranoid in common with all parents he maintains we all have our vulnerabilities our areas of concern our fears says furedi we all have something that can be played on and opened up and which then becomes the basis of fear in our parenting so furedi is on a mission he wants to make us aware of our paranoia so we can all cool it and be a bit more rational where looking after our kids is concerned thus the message of his new book paranoid parenting is stop listening to the experts tear up the handbook and follow your instincts where your child is concerned you know best of course there is a certain paradox to all this since furedi himself is a type of expert a sociologist at the university of kent and before you follow his advice never to read another parenting book he would love you to buy this one his ideas were formed he says after he became a father at the relatively advanced age of and discovered that parenting had changed rather a lot in the decades between his own boyhood and that of his son in particular what he noticed was that children were no longer left to their own devices he describes it as a colonisation of the world of children by adults as a consequence he says adults not only inhabit but control the lives of children to an alarming and unhealthy extent for furedi whose book the culture of fear examined the way risk is perceived in society the most obvious manifestation of this control centres on fears about childrens safety the real risks he argues are magnified by irrational fears and so kids freedom and creativity are being limited while jacob is encouraged to play outside the furedis home in faversham kent many children are kept indoors out of harms way but the harm furedi would have us believe is largely imagined yes we read a lot about child abduction murder and paedophilia but the risks to our own children from these evils are minuscule our fears are fed by study after alarmbellringing study alerting us to this or that childhood danger furedi disputes the idea that most of these studies originate in universities like his own in fact he says many are market research reports masquerading as more serious analyses the media are the villains of the piece and here there is a whiff of furedis past as a member of the revolutionary communist party whose magazine living marxism had an unerring instinct for controversy and an abiding contempt for the bourgeois press but the result he says is a generation of parents who believe that their children are at real risk and who are overreacting in their efforts to protect them when i ask people why they limit their childrens activities in a particular way says furedi they always say i couldnt live with myself if anything happened in other words theyre talking about themselves not about their children all this worry he believes is casting a shadow over family life take cot death for example furedi says that when he and his wife ann were expecting jacob the risks of cot death were often mentioned every mother i know admits to having worried at some point that their child is at risk he notes its emblematic of the campaign that weve created the effect of this climate of fear on parents is exacerbated by the fact that more and more is expected from them argues furedi take education todays parents are expected to be amateur teachers involved in every part of their childrens schoolwork its certainly not enough to leave it to the school i think that degrades education because it means politicians can ignore the problems of schools what im saying is that weve established this culture in which parents have a direct sense of responsibility for everything that happens to their children what this means is that weve lost our autonomy furedi thinks that because we now feel we have to take responsibility for every part of our childrens lives we take every threat to their safety too seriously its not worth altering your behaviour and being on red alert for what are relatively small risks he maintains weve got to accept that life contains risks and its far better to be aware of them than to let them enslave our lives the counterargument to all this is that todays parents are more knowledgeable about certain areas of parenting and more involved in their childrens lives than parents in the s and s but furedi is having none of this first he says it is naive to argue that the information we are being fed about say health risks in pregnancy is widening our choice or improving our parenting in fact they often lead to enforced conformity take the us where in some areas pregnant women can be arrested for drinking in public he says what begins as advice ends up as coercion furedi concedes that there may be a positive aspect to parents being more involved in the lives of their children but adds that the danger is it becomes compulsive what starts as involvement becomes this infinite process and you lose the ability to draw a line between what your children should be doing on their own and what adults should be doing furedi describes his own childhood he grew up in hungary in the s as a happy one despite a lack of material wealth and a father who had to work a hour week interestingly he admits that his mother who had survived imprisonment in a concentration camp was overprotective his own desire to be handsoff about jacobs upbringing and to persuade the rest of us to take the same approach is at least partly a reaction to that our own parents probably did a reasonable job given the constraints they were under and i dont think its helpful to criticise them furedi denies that he is harking back to a golden age when parents left their kids to get on with growing up and did not meddle so much although it is difficult to dismiss entirely the thought that somewhere inside he does believe that todays kids are worse off than previous generations what he says is that there is no model from the past for good practice in parenting every generation has to deal with the difficulties around it and do the best it can but the bottom line is if we stopped trying so hard we would make a better job of bringing up our kids and if we ignored most of the advice we are bombarded with we would do a better job still paranoid parenting by frank furedi is published by penguin press readers can order a copy for including firstclass uk pampp freephone or send your order with a uk cheque payable to the guardian to park royal road london nw ln

be doing on their own and what adults should be doing furedi describes his own childhood he grew up in hungary in the s as a happy one despite a lack of material wealth and a father who had to work a hour week interestingly he admits that his mother who had survived imprisonment in a concentration camp was overprotective his own desire to be handsoff about jacobs upbringing and to persuade the rest of us to take the same approach is at least partly a reaction to that our own parents probably did a reasonable job given the constraints they were under and i dont think its helpful to criticise them furedi denies that he is harking back to a golden age when parents left their kids to get on with growing up and did not meddle so much although it is difficult to dismiss entirely the thought that somewhere inside he does believe that todays kids are worse off than previous generations what he says is that there is no model from the past for good practice in parenting every generation has to deal with the difficulties around it and do the best it can but the bottom line is if we stopped trying so hard we would make a better job of bringing up our kids and if we ignored most of the text: a controversial new book on childrearing to be published this week will urge parents to let their children take more risks and stop panicking about playground bullies and paedophiles the books author frank furedi reader in sociology at the university of kent argues that parents obsession with the safety of their children is more damaging than the risks themselves paranoid parenting abandon your anxieties and be a good parent says parents should be wary of traditional childcentred experts and urges the government not to meddle in the family and parenting penelope leach britains leading childcare authority and a target of the book said almost everyone who writes about children has something to offer and i dont understand why we end up being so aggressive with each other however she said that she had some fundamental disagreements with paranoid parenting he concludes that governments should not get involved but i cannot think of a more appropriate issue for policy than childrens issues furedi is no stranger to controversy he was a prominent member of the revolutionary communist party a trotskyite group whose members founded the magazine living marxism or lm the magazine was forced to close last year after it lost a libel case against itn which it had accused of doctoring footage of serb concentration camps lm was one of the few british publications sympathetic to the serb cause in his new book furedi argues children are introduced to the culture of fear from the moment they are born this begins with new measures to guard against hospital babynappers and is followed by guidelines about the minimal risk of cot death arriving home they are surrounded by an army of midwives health visitors and doctors they then hem themselves in even more by buying childcare books as their babies grow their insecurity makes them easy prey for manufacturers furedi is also concerned about the mixed messages in the news one day a national charity will be castigating parents for turning their children into couch potatoes the next he argues it will announce that letting children play outdoors on their own is a form of child abuse add to this fears about accidents in the home and paedophiles and its small wonder many parents are inclined to be overprotective says furedi fear of abuse means no one dares to watch over children who are outside without their adult owners but in watching their backs they are undermining what furedi calls adult solidarity the casual neighbourhood safety net has disappeared leaving children who do venture beyond their front doors far less protected than they were before the author also attacks dr jane healy a childcare specialist who received publicity last year for telling a parenting conference that young children should not be put in front of computers because this changed the way their brains were wired supporters of healy have said her argument was misrepresented in media scare stories that followed they say that her central argument was that parents need not think they have to buy all the latest educational gizmos as research showed the children learnt more when parents put their child on their knee and read them a storybook a position not dissimilar to furedis according to paranoid parenting it is cruel to keep children inside they need room to explore the world around them they need time to make their own friendships in their own way without an army of anxious adults monitoring their every movement but at the heart of the furedi argument is an attack on government interference and in particular labours social policy the politicisation of parenthood is a failure of the political imagination unable to work out effective social policies that can tackle the real problems facing british society some politicians have been persuaded that if they can reeducate parents everything would turn out fine politicians who have failed to provide britain with a decent system of education somehow assume that nevertheless they are fit to educate parents furedi told the observer that he hopes the book will help parents put their anxieties in perspective and understand that most of the really big issues that plague parents have little to do with problems instrinsic to childrearing he believes they should turn their backs on experts and build on their own experiences rather than seek support from professionals in all matters hed like parents to pay more attention to friends and relatives familiar with their way of life critics of furedi such as guardian columnist catherine bennett argue that he is simply giving parents more to worry about writing last week bennett quoted furedis concern that playground areas are now covered with rubber to limit the damage when a child falls should they perhaps be constructed from something more challenging shards of broken glass say or the traditional grit which was once so successful at lacerating young knees

text: families with children were the biggest recipients of recently married gordon browns generosity there are increases in direct financial help for those with children whether lone parents or couples and there are greater benefits for women having babies but anyone tempted to follow the advice of one tabloid which dubbed this a breed for britain budget should take care many of the benefit improvements will not kick in for months or even two years babies conceived now in a spirit of budget euphoria will not qualify some gains are limited to the less welloff or barred for the wealthiest and most are not paid out automatically parents have to apply and that could involve means testing and form filling heres our guide to whats on offer when it will be paid and most importantly how to ensure you get what is due maternity pay statutory maternity pay smp is a nonmeanstested benefit paid to those about to have a baby or who have just had a baby they must earn enough to be in the national insurance net although there is no minimum ni contribution it is currently set at a week and is due to rise to a week in april and a year after that from april the payments will be made for weeks instead of the current weeks these amounts are paid direct by employers who can then reclaim a proportion they are minimum levels many women will receive more thanks to contractual obligations these may not necessarily be increased in the same proportion women who have paid past national insurance contributions but who do not qualify for smp can claim maternity allowance at the same rate ask for form ma at a local benefits agency if this applies to you paternity leave fathers will get two weeks paid leave on the same basis as smp from april it will be paid by employers who will be free to offer more generous arrangements paid adoption leave to be paid at the same rate as smp sure start maternity grant this meanstested lump sum benefit applies to some low income families a year it will be increased from to in april the prebudget report last autumn abolished the savings limit for applicants details from the benefits agency childrens tax credit starting in april parents of children aged up to will receive a week via paypackets providing they complete an inland revenue form which they can get from their local tax office the sum will be paid irrespective of the number of children and will be tapered so that higher paid parents will not receive the credit families where one or both parents earn up to will receive the full credit those where the higher or only earner has an annual salary of to will receive lower amounts while those earning more will receive nothing from april the higher earnings level rises to helpline baby bonus this is an extension of childrens tax credit it will be paid on a similar basis to ctc to parents of children born after april for the first year of the childs life they will receive an additional a week tax credit making in all paid through the paye system by their employer provided they have sufficient earnings most new parents with earnings will be able to apply via an inland revenue form working families tax credit this is a meanstested benefit to top up the wages of low paid workers with children administered by the inland revenues tax credit office the basic credit goes up from to next month and by a further a week on june wftc claimants should get a minimum a week claim on form wftc from benefits agencies helpline childcare tax credit this is part of working families tax credit and cannot be claimed on its own from june the limit that can be claimed for childcare by qualifying families goes up from a week to for those with one child needing care and from to for those with more than one child child benefit a nonmeanstested amount which is currently paid at the same rate to all families with children regardless of income or hours worked it goes up from to for the first or only child and from to for subsequent children claim on form ch for the first child ch for subsequent children vat there is no vat payable on clothes or shoes for children but the definition of a child size has stayed unchanged since the s children now grow faster and mature earlier new rules will attempt to distinguish between clothes aimed at older children and those aimed at adults reducing costs there will be separate rules for boys and girls small women and men who can fit into child sizes will also benefit the low incomes tax reform group welcomed the a year increase in childrens tax credit over the previously announced rate but it has fundamental concerns about how the credit will operate in practice it says the interaction between this credit and the working families tax credit means many of those encouraged to take up by the wftc will find the ctc is reduced to a mere a year instead of the full calling both a tax credit is difficult to follow for most people while dealing with ctc through tax codings is bound to lead to confusion

text: there are to be large increases in maternity pay aimed at making it easier for new mothers to have a period at home after their child is born before they return to work statutory maternity pay or smp at present paid at a flat rate of a week after the first six weeks is to go up to from next year and to from april maternity allowance paid to selfemployed women and others not eligible for smp will go up by the same rate all women entitled to smp or maternity allowance approximately a year will get either the new flat rate or as under present rules of their previous average earnings if that is lower from april the period of maternity pay at the enhanced rate will also increase from to weeks giving mothers on smp or maternity allowance entitlement to a further eight weeks of pay working fathers will also for the first time be given the right to two weeks paid paternity leave at the same flat rate from april adoptive parents who are entitled to only weeks unpaid leave will be paid for adoption leave for the same period and at the same flat rate as smp adoptive parents will be able to choose which of them takes time off work and receives payment from april the sure start maternity grant will go up from the oneoff payment to the grant is part of the governments programme aimed at promoting the wellbeing of children under four years old in britains most disadvantaged areas it is payable to all low income families provided they meet basic health check requirements for their child the increase will benefit some families on income related benefits and tax credits every year christine gowdridge the director of the maternity alliance said the increase in maternity pay over two years is very significant especially for low incomes families a real boost at a time when they need it most john edmonds general secretary of the gmb public service workers union said gordon brown has thrown a lifeline to thousands of working mothers many working women are forced into a devils choice between spending time with their child during the vital first months or leaving their child to earn income to support it through its early years these measures will go a long way to freeing women from the maternity trap kate green the director of the national council for one parent families said this is a tremendous step

text: despite longstanding equal opportunity legislation and a climate of political correctness women bosses are still seen as different from their male counterparts not necessarily better or worse but different all the same gender is commonly supposed to influence how they deal with their peers and subordinates but are there really any significant differences between working for a man and working for a woman moreover if there are how should you make the best of the situation if we are to believe dr john gray male and female bosses are worlds apart the author of the best selling selfhelp book men are from mars women are from venus writes at length about the differences he concludes that men are interested in objects and things whereas women are interested in people and feelings many dismiss this theory as inaccurate sexist nonsense angela ishmael head of the dignity at work community initiative at the industrial society says that what makes one boss different from another has much less to do with gender than management style and management style she argues is based on your bosss business sense and is independent of biology most of the convincing academic research in this field suggests that if anything male and female managers are more alike than dissimilar this finding was most recently confirmed in the edition of women in management current research the few differences that do appear to exist can be simplified dr sandi mann author of psychology goes to work and senior lecturer at lancaster university says that women tend to be more cooperative teamorientated and peopleorientated they are concerned about individuals and keen for everyone to participate men she says on the whole are less consultative and more authoritarian however points out dr mann these are sweeping generalisations and are by no means true of all men or all women richard branson has a reputation real or spun for a caring sharing collaborative relationship with his staff the same could hardly be said for margaret thatcher so for you the question is not how do you deal with a boss that is either male or female but how do you deal with a boss thats either democratic or at the other extreme dictatorial professor marilyn davidson of the manchester school of management at umist is considered something of an expert when it comes to these sorts of questions she offers the following advice for those who have a letsdothistogether boss dont try to get away with doing the minimum letting those around you do your work for you dont shrug off responsibility for yourself do take the initiative do get involved do ask for guidance if it is not forthcoming meanwhile for those who toil under a doasisay boss dont be arrogant dont be bolshie do open up the lines of communication do seek out opportunities for more work freedom do try to empower yourself in the office as best as possible remember that regardless of your particular boss just because you dont like them doesnt mean you have to lump them you have choices says professor davidson you can always walk away and go elsewhere

text: they were supposed to change the maledominated world of politics for ever but the socalled blair babes have had a battle on their hands even to survive fighting against blatant sexism and towering male egos to succeed in interviews for a new report female parliamentarians have attacked a macho culture in the commons accusing male colleagues of acting like prima donnas and getting their egos massaged by public displays of rebellion against the government at least two complained of sexual harassment in westminster such as name calling and obscene gestures while others said they feared promoting feminist causes could damage their careers the research conducted by politics lecturer dr sarah childs concludes that despite such obstacles the female parliamentary intake of has quietly made a major difference to the commons and to women voters lives it cites policies from crackdowns on domestic violence to better childcare and action against forced marriages as examples of female mps success arguing that many of their most notable successes such as watering down the asylum bill may never have been made public but childs whose paper will be presented to the political studies association conference in london later this month said she emerged with sympathy for the mps i was told they would be these terrible plastic politicians but i didnt think they were that kind of identikit shoulderpadded madeover women at all she said a lot of them were women who perhaps were firstgeneration higher educated and who were passionate about things like poverty and social exclusion they felt that they were set up to fail that they were expected to come in and make massive changes overnight which was completely unrealistic and that that has been hung around their necks they feel it was about misogyny in the press and that they couldnt win if you do something you are just acting like a woman and not looking after anyone else if you dont make a change thats because you are pathetic childs interviewed more than half of the labour women first entering parliament in repeating most of her interviews in the strongest response came from repeated public criticism that the new women mps were too scared to rebel against the government in votes as men did one said the difference with men was that we are not prima donnas while a second added we are committed to doing politics differently not to trashing people not to rubbishing people in public others said the macho thrill of voting against the government might be less likely to succeed than quietly buttonholing ministers to alter legislation and a fourth added women do their business differently they are not prone to getting up and talking if theyve got nothing to say they like to get things done rather than have their egos massaged however the paper warns that the women mps did not always succeed their protests over boxer and convicted rapist mike tyson coming to britain to fight were brushed aside by home secretary jack straw and one told childs the cosy image of a supportive labour sisterhood was misleading as they felt like a threatened species competing with each other to get on i would say that dog eat dog cat eat cat is just as strong if not stronger between the female fraternity of the house than the male she added the mass influx of labour women into parliament in fuelled by using allwomen shortlists to promote female candidates prompted initial euphoria but the atmosphere quickly soured with whispering that the female newcomers were too timid and asked patsy questions of ministers it culminated in labour backbencher brian sedgemore describing his female colleagues as obedient stepford wives childs concludes that the evidence shows the election of labour women mps to the house of commons has made a difference despite the criticism however the report suggests some female mps are less sympathetic to men with some reporting that male constituents had less genuine problems wanting text: the suffragettes chained themselves to the railings outside no to give women the vote to give them power we might have to resort to even more drastic measures naked hunger strikers surrounding millbank perhaps or guntoting feminists hijacking a concorde nothing else seems to work the election of women mps failed to give women clout so did the ministry for women cherie blairs principled stand on parental leave had some impact but even marrying off gordon brown to a successful professional sarah macaulay has failed to change the macho mood in politics in the beginning there was hope during the election labour had understood that if they wanted womens votes theyd have to have women in their ranks accordingly we saw and heard a lot of margaret beckett margaret jay tessa jowell mo mowlam harriet harman clare short and barbara follett trade union men who for so long had lent labour a decidedly masculine air were hushed and diluted promises of better childcare and parental leave wooed women voters the courtship worked women traditionally more likely to vote conservative switched allegiance to tony blair and then suddenly the honeymoon was over yes tony placed a few women in high positions and he delivered on childcare and parental leave as well as on the minimum wage which helped millions of women at the bottom of the earnings scale but the real power brokers were still brown mandelson campbell prescott men whose politicking was conducted over takeaway curries and beer as they watched football on the telly with the women blair seemed to be engaged in a different game a political version of the weakest link during which the gimleteyed dominator expelled harriet harman silenced mo mowlam and clare short snubbed barbara follett yes margaret jay led the house of lords but shes decided shes had enough of politics now and yes margaret beckett hovers in the wings but shes a reproach not a triumph this election has exposed the sad truth politics is still a mens game its the one theme that unifies the three main parties apart from cartoon caricatures such as the mummy and doris karloff the women have gone awol only one candidate in five from the major parties is a woman and there will be fewer in the next parliament echo research monitored mentions of individual politicians in national newspapers in their coverage of the first two weeks only one woman ann widdecombe appears in the top ten cherie blair whos kept a lower profile than during the election and ffion hague who dons blue smiles and has her husband answer questions for her have received five times the mention of any woman politician jackie ashley the political editor of the new statesman challenged gordon brown at his press conference last friday to explain why female ministers and party spokeswomen appear on campaign platforms only to keep mum however it is not just faces on a platform it is the issues that get discussed campaign coverage has concentrated on macho rows about europe tax and crime when all the evidence shows that these are the issues which make women switch off health and education are consistently ranked by women as more important little wonder that a mori poll revealed that during the past week the proportion of women who are certain or likely to vote has dropped from per cent to per cent feminists cant hide their disappointment as rosie boycott puts it we founded spare rib the campaigning feminist magazine years ago and since then a lot has changed for women but a great deal hasnt where are the improved childcare services why is there still a per cent pay gap between men and women at the lower income level tess kingham elected as one of the new labour wave of new women in is retiring as mp for gloucester after just one term she says she has found the commons a frustrating place to operate more alarmingly she has found that the culture there is a barrier to being an effective mp even so she has been effective a grassroots mp who successfully lobbied for millions to refurbish a local hospital for changes to the law on fire safety with a campaign for sprinklers that has gone international and for national screening for cystic fibrosis she also asked uncomfortable questions on arms trading the public are fed up with all that yahbooey stuff its ok for the public school oxbridge boys but its a turnoff for most people particularly women and the young she explains kingham had twins while in office looked after by a willing husband but denies this has been the main reason for her departure its wider than the childcare issue the chamber frustrated me it was difficult to speak and when people did it was little more than point scoring oona king is staying the course and seeking reelection as labour mp for bethnal green and bow in find im the only woman there king does not have a visibility problem in fact insiders talk of her as one of labours rising stars shes bright beautiful and black and just outspoken enough to make the media and her constituents feel shes a real person rather than an onmessage automaton when she came into parliament with the last intake she was only and unprepared for the masculine conventions of parliamentary politics parliament is based on seniority you dont get to the top jobs or even to ask questions unless you have held a senior position she said and by definition that keeps most women mps out of the power structure apart from the structure the very schedule of parliament is inimical to women with families or even as in kings case with a partner hes told me hes going to leave me if this carries on she says as we drive off to visit a constituent at a nearby council estate we drive in her renault clio along streets that are strewn with rubbish half the buildings are derelict welcome to my beautiful constituency she jokes and there is little sign of the urban renewal that has transformed neighbouring shoreditch i dont mind the work load but its from am to midnight and often were listening to eric forth debating whether there should be an ice cream van outside hyde park the denning point housing estate is a grungy tower block that plays host to crack gangs muggers and prostitutes this is according to jeannie whos come down from her eighthfloor flat to escort us through this shithole she points out a shabby prefab hut at the foot of the tower block where three bengali girls are playing its where they do the ayatollahs learning she barks king whos wearing a salwar kameez out of respect for the muslim family shell be visiting later gives me a wink jeannes mollified by her hug and by the way i recoil when she shows us the vomit and used condoms in the stairwell by the time we get upstairs to her flat and her husband bundu whos from sierra leone shes in high spirits oonas here she chirps while bundu fetches a bottle of taittinger champagne from the fridge who said champagne socialists only lived in islington king speaks of our problems and what we must do she links arms with bundu when he fills her champagne flute and puts her head close to jeannies for the photographer i recognise the tactic perfected by mowlam and short this is the woman politician casting off the deference and blurring the boundaries between personal and political showing the electorate that youre there for them always accessible improved public services more and better childcare the abolition of gender gap wage differential these are among the issues dear to women but at stake is something even more fundamental at a time when representative democracy is under attack from the ever more powerful corporate world and from public apathy politicians cannot afford to ignore the rights of half of the population to have a say in the decision making keeping women politicians mum will only keep women voters at bay and fuel our suspicion that the women who chained themselves to the railings of no got us a vote but not much else the moment that promised a new dawn if women were the only voters labour would have won just two elections since if only men voted neither ted heath in nor john major in would have been returned as prime ministers at the last election the swing towards labour was per cent among women and per cent among men a historic closing of labours gender gap women mps were elected at the last election current predictions are that will text: a single mother who cracked under the strain of bringing up three children alone was jailed for months yesterday for abandoning the family without food heating or even a toothbrush while she took a mediterranean holiday the yearold woman illegally sold her child benefit book to top up a maximum withdrawal of and pay for the week in malta after relatives refused to help her out with childcare her sons aged five seven and were left at home in newcastle upon tyne with the gas cut off bare electricity wires in bedrooms and a meagre supply of clothes to last them the week newcastle crown court heard the woman who cannot be named for legal reasons had been on the verge of a breakdown but had behaved with selfish and callous disregard for her children david hodson the recorder told her no court would tolerate behaviour which endangered children the court heard the woman who admitted three charges of child cruelty through neglect had a record of involvement with the citys social services with her two older children placed on the at risk register in before abandoning the family last july for her holiday she had tried to leave them with her mother whom she said was a vindictive cow anne richardson prosecuting said she had not even told her sons that she would be away for a week she had simply left a note pinned to the door of their north shields home saying she needed time to herself inside the house was in an appalling state dirty with bags of rubbish on the floor cigarette ends everywhere no washing facilities for the children and no sheets or bedding said ms richardson the fridge was empty and there was broken glass on the floor and prescribed drugs lying around the bare wires in the bedrooms were left after bulb fittings had been wrenched out ms richardson said the family had been traumatised and none of the children wanted anything further to do with their mother she had agreed not to fight for custody and social services were hoping to find an adoptive family the court heard that the yearold had caused great concern at school where he used to arrive unkempt and dirty before he was suspended and then excluded ms richardson said he was described by his teacher as always very hungry he would try to return to school with his brothers even after exclusion paul sloane qc in mitigation said the woman had gone straight to the police on her return to confess

usual forest of besuited hands did not rise from the press seats butted in ahead of ms morris to answer a question on why so few women feature in the election campaign starting to contradict the text: oh why cant a woman by more like a man the facetious response to professor higgins in my fair lady would be because they are different however the professor is not alone in relating better to men than women and lamenting rather than accepting the differences between the sexes and that includes some interviewers youll hear it said that most interviewers make up their minds about candidates in the first seconds of an interview but in addition to this they may also treat male and female candidates differently according to recent research by city university interviewers not only use different criteria to judge male and female interviewees but the questions asked during the interview are sometimes phrased differently for men and women the purpose of the study was to assess the benefits of telephone interviews and how they compare with facetoface interviews the graduate milkround although well established is expensive and time consuming the researchers were keen to establish whether telephone interviews were an effective way of reducing the cost and time involved with selecting graduates for positions in a large multinational organisations the researchers taped interviews with applicants to a graduate training programme men and women the applicants were interviewed on the telephone and facetoface as part of the selection process and interviewers were asked to rate applicants after each interview the questions asked by the interviewer in both types of interview were noted and analysed the results of the study surprised jo silvester senior lecturer in organisational psychology at city university telephone interviews were rated lower overall but we found that male applicants performed better in telephone interviews while female applicants performed better in facetoface interviews she explains interestingly men were asked significantly more openended questions than women who were asked more closed questions particularly during the telephone interviews and the significance of this well openended questions provide more of an opportunity for an interviewee to talk and sell themselves men were more likely to be asked questions like how do you think whereas women tend to be asked do you think where the answer is simply a yes or a no if female applicants then proceeded to elaborate when asked a closed question they may be viewed as pushy explains jo the success of women in facetoface interviews could be because women tend to be more sensitive to and more dependent on interviewers nonverbal cues perhaps they are disadvantaged when these are removed hence their lower scorings in the telephone interviews the research suggests that in facetoface interviews women convey more control more acceptance of responsibility and a willingness to discuss difficult topics whereas men tend to focus on positive situations although the city study was a small sample and it is difficult to draw any conclusive findings jo has found similar results in another study she carried out which compared facetoface and telephone interviews of male and female solicitors at a large law firm in this study the results had also showed that women tended to be asked more closed questions compared to men at the time i thought that it was a one off but the findings from this research do suggest that men and women are treated differently during selection interviews christine fitzmaurice a psychologist at career psychology cautions against generalisations based on such a small sample there may be differences in the way in which male and female candidates are treated during interviews but this could be down a number of reasons for example the interviewer may simply be having a bad day that is why the interview should be just one part of a selection process which should also include group exercises and role play she says interviewer bias can be reduced by panel interviews where more than one person is involved both in the interview and selection process one of the advantages of panel interviews is that a recruitment decision will not be made on the preconceptions of one person says christine

text: women lobby journalists are split on whether the socalled oldboy network discriminates against them in political briefings many feel the problem lies with the political parties who put female spokeswomen on the platforms at briefings but deflect questions to their male counterparts the sunday expresss political editor julia hartleybrewer dismissed as whingeing the suggestion politicians deliberately exclude female journalists its not the calling of questions thats the issue she said were massively outnumbered so its obvious more men are going to be called most of the political editors are male and the politicians tend to go for the big hitters she added the financial timess political correspondent rosemary bennett said the problem is not that questions are not taken from female journalists but that they are deflected to male mps if a question comes in on health and theres a male and a female minister the question will get diverted to the male minister she said bbc radio lives fi glover who is not a lobby journalist said she thought the bias was not against women but towards the most senior lobby journalists most of whom are men but one senior female political journalist said the fact most of the political editors of newspapers and broadcasters were men was an indictment of the sexism that still permeates westminster basically elinor goodman the channel news political editor always gets her questions in and theres a couple of others but the rest of the female journalists are quite a way down the pecking order ms goodman the new statemans jackie ashley and itns jo andrews are considered to be the biggest hitters among the female lobby correspondents related stories reporters take stand against sexist briefings itv issues challenge to blair mediaguardiancouk special report general election and the media

men but they could have campaigned better for women and children yesterday yvette cooper public health minister announced m for creches for nurses a necessity for recruiting staff but as a contribution to national childcare week it only acted as a reminder of labours biggest missed opportunity this government has done a great deal more than any other to provide childcare yet a recent poll showed the great majority of parents have never heard of the national childcare strategy it has not exactly tripped off the lips of the prime minister or chancellor each day large sums have been paid out a big programme is at last slowly rolling out and the number of childcare places is gradually rising the manifesto promises m children will have places by with one for every lone parent still not nearly enough for the m children under eight but an improvement in there was one place for every nine children under eight now there is one for every seven parents on basic rate can get a childcare tax credit of up to where before there was nothing so all this money is spent but there is no branding no message no election talk or understanding of its fundamental importance to families there is still ambivalence about whether it is a genuinely national strategy for all so far it is a strategy for the poorest though not all and for the richest who pay for their own now some a week in london but nothing for warwick woman the strategy suffers the classic problem of labours other social policies each local authority has an early years partnership which now finds it has to bid for office recently funded nurseries discovering american research showing how every spent on nursery education saved in crime and social dysfunction later it is a muddle of a strategy but that it exists at all is entirely due to women ministers pushing it through persuading the chancellor that childcare saves money in the end if the government were more farsighted they would take this patchwork and weld it into a single promise there will be a childrens centre in every area there will be childrens palaces for every baby born with clinics toddler groups creches and nurseries afterschool clubs and adult training all under one roof they would be a symbol for labours social message making real to everyone who uses them what is happening to end child poverty improve education and ease the strain on families rich and poor using them together the day care trusts campaign is gaining ground their aspiration is for childrens centres the missing piece of the welfare state as urgently needed by ordinary families as by the poor electorally labour should have seized hold of this it will be expensive maybe as much as bn but it need not be promised all at once a rolling programme starting with the poor eventually reaching the leafy suburbs would take time it doesnt have to be free with fees affordable to each purse now this would have caught the imagination of the women who groan at the artificial jousting on their television screens as it is when nurseries and afterschool clubs do open the government will get scant thanks or recognition was it the local authority was it the lottery or a voluntary group it needs a single brand to make this a labour flagship etched into labours identity as firmly as the founding the nhs but the men at the top still think it something marginal so text: mothers will be able to take up to a year off work around the birth of their baby under an overhaul of the complex maternity rules unveiled by the government yesterday the move which extends unpaid leave by three months was welcomed by family campaigners though there were calls for the government to grant new parents the right to work flexible or reduced hours ministers are still debating the option which has not been ruled out but is met with caution in downing street because of business opposition reinforced by the cbi yesterday in the latest of a string of preelection announcements targeted at women and the family the health secretary alan milburn will today give details of a m upgrade of maternity units across the country designed to give mothers more choice over how and where their babies are delivered he will address the royal college of midwives the day after members warned that they felt their role was undervalued and pressed for more government funding for the service steps to extend maternity leave are part of a package of measures to improve and streamline maternity rights while seeking to keep employers on board in march the chancellor gordon brown announced in the budget an increase in the flat rate of statutory maternity pay from a week to a week from april it will be paid for weeks instead of the present the latest reform will add an extra weeks to the maximum of weeks which women can take before and after the birth of a child it will also simplify the framework of pay and leave by standardising the qualifying periods a move to please employers frustrated at the bureaucracy of the current system mothers will have to give employers an extra weeks notice of when they intend to start and return times the cbi said employers wanted even more notice the trade and industry secretary stephen byers said with more women in work it is vital to put in place measures that allow working mothers to combine being a good parent with holding down a job the right to take a years maternity leave will make a real difference to a childs first year of life the maternity alliance which has long pressed for improved maternity pay and leave welcomed the changes as a step in the right direction but warned that many families earning just too much to qualify for benefits could find themselves unable to afford to take up the unpaid leave the national family and parenting institute also praised moves to bring british parents rights closer to those of their european counterparts campaigners argued that a right to come back to work on flexitime or part time would encourage more women to return to work one in three new mothers do not return to work but the dti estimated that if of those went back to work employers could save m a year in recruitment mr milburn will today invite the maternity units in england to bid for extra funding to update equipment and increase staffing to provide expectant mothers with greater continuity of care he wants the nhs to make home births more easily available and to provide more homelike birthing suites in hospitals

text: mothers will be able to take up to a year off work around the birth of their baby under an overhaul of the complex maternity rules unveiled by the government yesterday the move which extends unpaid leave by three months was welcomed by family campaigners though there were calls for the government to grant new parents the right to work flexible or reduced hours ministers are still debating the option which has not been ruled out but is met with caution in downing street because of business opposition reinforced by the cbi yesterday in the latest of a string of preelection announcements targeted at women and the family the health secretary alan milburn will today give details of a m upgrade of maternity units across the country designed to give mothers more choice over how and where their babies are delivered he will address the royal college of midwives the day after members warned that they felt their role was undervalued and pressed for more government funding for the service steps to extend maternity leave are part of a package of measures to improve and streamline maternity rights while seeking to keep employers on board in march the chancellor gordon brown announced in the budget an increase in the flat rate of statutory maternity pay from a week to a week from april it will be paid for weeks instead of the present the latest reform will add an extra weeks to the maximum of weeks which women can take before and after the birth of a child it will also simplify the framework of pay and leave by standardising the qualifying periods a move to please employers frustrated at the bureaucracy of the current system mothers will have to give employers an extra weeks notice of when they intend to start and return times the cbi said employers wanted even more notice the trade and industry secretary stephen byers said with more women in work it is vital to put in place measures that allow working mothers to combine being a good parent with holding down a job the right to take a years maternity leave will make a real difference to a childs first year of life the maternity alliance which has long pressed for improved maternity pay and leave welcomed the changes as a step in the right direction but warned that many families earning just too much to qualify for benefits could find themselves unable to afford to take up the unpaid leave the national family and parenting institute also praised moves to bring british parents rights closer to those of their european counterparts campaigners argued that a right to come back to work on flexitime or part time would encourage more women to return to work one in three new mothers do not return to work but the dti estimated that if of those went back to work employers could save m a year in recruitment mr milburn will today invite the maternity units in england to bid for extra funding to update equipment and increase staffing to provide expectant mothers with greater continuity of care he wants the nhs to make home births more easily available and to provide more homelike birthing suites in hospitals

substantial proportion of the doctors spending their next decade working towards the top jobs their report said but difficulties lay in their way two years ago women still made up only of consultants in medical specialities in hospitals the proportion in top jobs that combined clinical and academic roles was far lower men were also showing signs of throwing off the traditional career culture which text: victory was a long time coming for the dinner ladies who served meals to miners the national union of mineworkers began a legal campaign to get them equal pay with other surface workers such as maintenance men in twentyfour years later after numerous court cases culminating in the house of lords four years ago their claim has been settled with an offer to pay the women most of whom no longer work in the industry around for each year of service as compensation for discrimination by british coal four months after an equal pay task force reported that women in fulltime jobs are still paid on average per cent less than male counterparts the new government is going to have to decide what to do about the gender gap on pay or whether to do anything at all the strongest recommendation of the task force was that employers should be forced to carry out regular audits of pay to establish that they are not paying men more than women the government preferred a voluntary approach but didnt rule out legislation the task force claimed that discrimination employers paying men more than women for work of equal value accounts for between and per cent of the difference in pay other factors were occupational segregation stereotyping in the jobs men and women do and the unequal impact of womens family responsibilities and yet its report said the vast majority of employers do not believe they have a gender pay gap and therefore do not believe an equal pay review is necessary it concluded that equal pay audits would have to be statutory the equal opportunities commissions case histories include a seamstress in a nursing home who successfully argued that her work was as skilled as that of male colleagues doing carpentry and plumbing who earned or an hour more and a telecoms manager who discovered after two years that she was paid less than her male predecessor few deny that the pay gap persists between men and women but the extent to which it is caused by discrimination is contested dominic johnson the cbis head of employee relations says were not denying that there is discrimination out there but were saying that most research conducted on the subject is flawed and the conclusions misleading because it looks at pay at aggregate level rather than that of individuals working for the same employer at a comparable level he argues that feminised jobs may have lower pay because women dont push so hard over pay money is not such a dominant factor in how women rate a job as it is for men he says adding women also have weaker bargaining power because they are bargaining on more than one front as well as pay they are also negotiating flexible working and time off for their caring responsibilities when statutory equal pay reviews were introduced in ontario canada he says the discrimination detected was minimal and vastly outweighed by the cost of the reviews julie mellor chair of the equal opportunities commission ripostes that until employers carry out these reviews we dont have the data to see how much is down to discrimination in pay systems she says a pay review is the only way an employer can ensure it is complying with equal pay laws and adds the burden argument doesnt hold water when you relate it to the burden on individual women who are not paid fairly examples of employers who already carry out the type of thorough review envisaged seem to be elusive the eoc is committed to developing a detailed twostage model to show employers how to conduct an equal pay review the idea is that employers should be able to carry out a quick check to see whether they may be discriminating and only if they are will they need to get involved in a more lengthy process the model should be ready for employers to try by the end of next year mellor says action is vital because the pay gap in the uk is the worst in europe in the netherlands the average hourly wage of a parttime woman worker is per cent less than that of a fulltime male in the uk it is per cent less few would deny that direct discrimination is only part of the story and that womens disproportionate share of family responsibilities as well as poor provision of childcare in the uk and continued stereotyping in career choices all play a significant part in the disparity between male and female incomes one of the main reasons women are still paid less than men is that the jobs which many women do are less well paid more than per cent of women workers are in just occupations where they are greatly overrepresented per cent work as sales assistants per cent as teachers per cent as secretaries and per cent as nurses none of them highly paid occupations by contrast more than per cent of engineers a much more highly paid profession are men by and large it is accepted that this is mainly the result of gender stereotyping which goes right back to the choices made at school but the eoc points out that some jobs such as teachers and bank tellers have seen pay fall in relative terms as they have become increasingly dominated by women in the private sector pay is left to market forces the argument being that people will only pay hairdressers what they think it is worth to have their hair done and that individual pay will vary according to the numbers of those willing to do the job in the public sector though pay levels are set by government and bear little relation to market forces in its most recent evidence to the pay review body before the latest public sector pay rises the royal college of nursing compared the salaries of nurses and police officers an occupation still dominated by men a nurses starting salary of used to be per cent less than that of a policeman it pointed out but the difference had grown to per cent within four years rachel dufton the rcns spokeswoman points out that there is a shortage of around nurses market forces would quickly drive up pay the equal opportunities com mission is planning to launch an awareness campaign this autumn on the stereotyped career choices young people make while this may persuade more girls to aspire to highlypaid careers as engineers and it professionals it may have a more difficult job persuading boys to train as nurses and shop assistants dufton says there is a danger that if you say dont go into stereotypical occupations you end up further devaluing the caring professions such as nursing in the long term the superior academic results being achieved by girls should go a long way towards narrowing the gender gap on pay but campaigners arent prepared to wait they want action from the government in the next five years
