text: womens satisfaction with their careers is plummeting because they receive such little support at work and home new research suggests only of all working women in the uk said they would work full time if they had a choice according to a survey out today another study to be published tomorrow claims that just are happy with the hours they put into their jobs a decade ago the majority were satisfied as female employees begin to break through the glass ceiling many take on extra responsibility at work while still shouldering heavy responsibilities at home nearly half of all working women have children under five tellingly of women said they could enjoy working if that was all they had to do but of full time employees said they did most of the household chores and more than of working mothers said they still bore most of the burden of childcare more than half of those interviewed said their companies made no allowances for women with children only said firms offered a creche to employees the survey of working women was carried out for top sant magazine in association with bupa its findings are reinforced by a study of working hours carried out for the economic and social research council which will be presented to the annual conference of acas the conciliation service tomorrow the survey of employees found that men and women were increasingly disillusioned with their careers the results were compared with an earlier study in of male employees were very or completely satisfied with their hours but by this year that had dropped to although their female counterparts were keener they were also losing enthusiasm much more rapidly in were satisfied with their work but in the new survey only said they were satisfied the majority of staff said they worked long hours because it was expected of them rather than to earn more money time not money is for many the barrier to enjoying a richer life said michael white of the policy studies institute which produced the research with a team from the london school of economics he added employee motivation will continue to ebb away unless employers wake up to the new reality dissatisfied employees are twice as likely as their more contented colleagues to look for a new job and much less willing to put in extra effort at work a survey carried out for the department for education and employment in november last year found that most men as well as women wanted more flexible arrangements such as job sharing and a reduced working week the government is considering proposals giving working mothers the right to work reduced hours for up to a year after their childs birth children do better at school are less likely to be involved in crime and have better social skills if fathers as well as mothers are involved in their upbringing a study said yesterday what good are dads was compiled from hundreds of research projects on families by charlie lewis a professor and psychologist at lancaster university

come into force until april the uk still will not approach the best in europe denmark where women receive weeks leave on of salary equivalent to weeks on full pay currently ranks top in europe according to the latest available data in contrast the majority of working women in britain qualify for a package which is equivalent to just weeks leave on full pay according to united nations statistics british maternity rights are even more miserly than those in dozens of african asian and latin american countries including for example angola congo brazil peru afghanistan india and bangladesh surprising consolation perhaps is the fact that pregnant women and new mothers fare even worse in the us and australia where there is no legal right at all to paid maternity leave in the us working mothers or fathers employed by companies with or more workers are entitled to take a total of only weeks unpaid leave for the birth of a child internet chatrooms on us parenting websites are of female workers receive paid maternity leave from their employers in the uk maternity rights are a complex and confusing minefield trying to understand just exactly what you can claim when you find you are pregnant is hugely complicated says national charity maternity alliance which has just published updated versions of its invaluable factsheets on maternity rights for both working and nonworking women working mothers you have a range of statutory workrelated rights both before and after your baby is born a key right is that it is against the law for your employer to treat you unfairly dismiss you or select you for redundancy for any reason connected with pregnancy childbirth or maternity leave pregnant women are entitled to time off work for antenatal checks without loss of pay you also have a right to alternative work or time off on full pay if your job is hazardous and you are currently pregnant gave birth within the last six months or are still breastfeeding ordinary maternity leave oml all women employees can claim weeks basic maternity leave with the right to return to exactly the same job no matter whether you are fulltime parttime the length of time text: in tony blair was swept into office by a country of hopeful women two million more votes were cast by women almost all of them for labour returning a record women to the commons the iconic photograph of blair surrounded by his women mps reflected a genuine expectation that we were about to discover a whole new way of conducting parliamentary democracy this morning the picture could not be more different after an election campaign defined by the utter invisibility of women an analysis of the abominably low turnout is very likely to show a substantial number of women abstaining and while so far this morning there is actually a net gain of one woman in the house we already know that numbers do not equal visibility when did labour lose sight of gender was it lulled into complacency by the sea of women that set apart the intake or convinced by the wave of female support that swung the election for it both have proved themselves to be costly chimeras that wary and conditional support is dissipating with midterm polls finding more women than men turning against the government it is ironic that although no other government has given women more on paper the minimum wage the childcare strategy a rise in maternity pay women have continued to declare themselves less satisfied while young women are least likely to vote meanwhile the concerns voiced by harriet harman and joan ruddock last conference that no more women would be selected without positive action have been borne out tenfold fewer than one in five candidates selected by the five main parties were women with labour fielding a total of female candidates out of seats bolstering the notion that male mps remain the norm the labour party has privately blamed the poor calibre of women coming forward for the dismal selection results but is it any wonder that women are reluctant to enter politics the commons is institutionally hostile to women not only because of its preference for text: the confidence of school leavers from the girl power generation is about to be shattered by glaring inequalities in the jobs market the equal opportunities commission warned yesterday in its annual report julie mellor the chairwoman contrasted young womens high performance at school and university with their experience of continuing discrimination in employment despite all their achievements young women still enter a far narrower range of jobs than young men they are already earning less than their male colleagues by the age of and they are less likely ever to reach the top of their field of work she said britain still has to address the glaring inequalities that so many women and men face otherwise we risk disappointing the high hopes of the girl power generation some of whom will be entering the job market before very long the commission received complaints about possible cases of discrimination in the year to the end of march they included calls about pregnancy and maternity issues on working hours on equal pay for like work and on sexual harassment compensation awards included for a financial accountant in devon who missed promotion while on maternity leave and for a truck driver from grangemouth who was made redundant after complaining about the sexist behaviour of her male colleagues ms mellor said sex equality was no longer just a womens issue in the workplace men as well as women need more choice about how they balance work with their lives outside work so that they are able to fulfil their role as fathers she said those who were not parents were also entitled to flexible working arrangements for example to provide time to take a course or be active in the community the commission will be campaigning for legislation to make employers carry out pay reviews to discover if there is a bias against women its other objectives include a right for employees to be taken seriously by their employers if they ask for more flexible working hours lady morgan the minister for women said the government was committed to helping young women fulfil their potential in the workplace the report identifies that stereotyping is damaging to both men and women and that flexible hours are important to all parents not just mums she said the government yesterday promised tougher action to stamp out racial harassment in the nhs john hutton the health minister published guidance to make managers take the problem more seriously and provide better support for ethnic minority staff the move followed disclosure in the guardian last month of a confidential government report showing that at least half the nhs frontline staff from ethnic minorities were victims of pervasive racial harassment last year the kings fund an independent health think tank that has led a campaign against racism in the nhs said the guidelines were a sign of good leadership julia neuberger the funds chief executive said in both medicine and nursing racial discrimination is a major cause of the nhs staffing crisis by sending out such clear signals that racist behaviour is not to be tolerated and by following that up with concerted action the government is not just helping those at the receiving end of racist abuse but benefiting everyone who works in or uses the nhs

text: so many burnt bras such little progress three decades after women first made pyres from their underwear in the name of equality they may have felt they were at last edging ahead in the battle of the sexes in fact they may already have lost the war the biggest ever study of male behaviour reveals the notsoshocking reality behind the progressive veneer of st century britain equality remains as illusory a goal as it was years ago despite the best efforts of a generation of feminist campaigners british men still enjoy the best of most worlds according to the study published today by the office for national statistics their incomes remain double that of the female half of the population even though equal pay legislation is held up as one of modern feminisms greatest triumphs and when they leave work men spend more time eating out gardening and watching television but in return do less than a quarter of the cooking and routine housework the study recognises that time has not entirely stood still men are less likely to be the sole breadwinner and are more likely to be cohabiting separated or divorced in many ways men today live in a different world from that of their fathers the report points out but in practical terms the differences are not that obvious according to the study the average gross income for british men was a week compared with for women womens average gross incomes peak in their mids at about a week before falling away during the main childrearing years and dropping below a week in their late s the comparable figures for men show a steady climb towards a sustained income plateau averaging about a week from to before gently declining towards the end of their working lives but never far enough to fall below women women may now be leaving text: an obligation on companies to reveal whether they treat women fairly is being drawn up by denise kingsmill the lawyer commissioned by the government to conduct a review of women at work modelled on codes for corporate governance executive pay and environmental responsibility to which all stock market listed firms are expected to comply companies will report to their shareholders each year on human capital management a statistical analysis of their approach to employment and promotion opportunities mrs kingsmill a lawyer who is deputy chairwoman of the competition commission believes firms should voluntarily conduct an annual survey of staff pay so comparisons can be made year on year between men and women in similar jobs her report will contain a guide to employers on best practice and also one for employees detailing what sort of treatment workers should expect she is shortly to ask the accounting standards board which sets out the accounting framework to which companies must adhere to consider beginning the work to require firms to include a section on human capital in reports her aim is to set out the practicalities in implementing the proposal made in a detailed report which she is due to deliver to patricia hewitt the trade and industry secretary and minister for women after the summer the report is likely to cause controversy the confederation of british industry opposes pay surveys or audits as increasing the administrative burden on firms the government is also facing criticism for appearing to back down on issues concerning women in the workplace and failing to resolve an gap in average hourly earnings between men and women mrs kingsmill was commissioned in april to conduct an independent review of equality and fairness at work she will also draw up measures for the public sector the proposals aimed at companies will not endorse positive discrimination they are intended to be advantageous to all employees the human capital management report which might be one page in an annual report would also allow men to see how they fared relative to their peers but mrs kingsmill admitted it would include a significant gender element the successful st century company is going to be one that manages its people best she said companies are always saying they are people businesses yet people go into the balance sheet as cost she believes her approach will win the backing of managers and will be supported by major investors as they increasingly consider social policies when taking investment decisions

text: men pay lip service to equal rights in the home while letting women do threequarters of the household chores new research suggests however women who are career high flyers do substantially less than women in lower paid work the study shows every increase in a womans annual income reduces the time she spends on chores every week by nearly two hours an oxford university researcher manyee kan discovered that women still did the bulk of the housework on average more than hours a week compared with about six hours for the average man the survey of couples did not count childcare as housework but looked at the division of labour in unpaid household work such as cooking cleaning and grocery shopping ms kan found that men were not much more inclined to pitch in around the home if their partners worked long hours the factors which did make a difference were the womans earning power how educated she was and how young this was because a higher income gave a woman more bargaining power in the family according to ms kan being able to buy more household goods did not make a difference she said most of the studies since the introduction of new technology have found that machines dont help to reduce workload if you raise efficiency you raise peoples expectations if you have a washing machine you wash more often rather than once a week however educated women tended to do less housework than women who had left school at the study showed working women with degrees spent about two hours less on chores than working women in households where both partners had only olevels or cses ms kan suggested this was because bettereducated women had a more egalitarian approach to how much of the housework their men ought to do the same applied to younger couples ms kan who presents her study at a conference at the institute for social and economic research university of essex today said men are taking a much more egalitarian attitude but it seems that women are still doing the lions share of the housework the attitude has changed but now we need to say to men if you think this way then go and do it ms kan said previous studies had showed that women tended to do the routine jobs around the house such as ironing while men opted for the nonroutine work the writer fay weldon in whose household the division of labour includes her husband taking out the rubbish while she cleans up the cat sick said that such studies missed the fact that housework could be fun more women like doing housework than men its a nesting instinct some women dont and dont do any but more men dont care what the house looks like women who are better off just employ other women to do the housework the rich have to find the energy to earn more money the idea is that housework is a terrible burden but it is just something you do to make your house look nice

text: the debate about whether or not to smack children took a new twist last night when a governmentbacked body insisted that violence achieves nothing and parents should be taught how to restrain themselves in order to reduce the risk of abuse reigniting controversy on whether recommendations about family life amount to a nanny state the findings will also disappoint campaigners who believe the government is shying away from outlawing smacking the report from the national family and parenting institute nfpi argues that smacking does not work and calls for a public education campaign on alternative methods of discipline but valerie riches founder of pressure group family and youth concern said this sounds like the nanny state raising its head again we would protest any attempt to remove from parents the right to make decisions about what goes on inside the family home many children are undisciplined and appropriate discipline is needed ministers have so far rejected demands text: as the summer holidays end the nights draw in and schools reopen adults all over the country may well be heaving a sigh of relief that there will be fewer children hanging about on the streets or the local shopping centre or playing in the park the way we all use public space is one of the most contentious areas of daily life and is often at the heart of disputes between young people and adults the importance of public space to childrens development and young peoples lives is poorly understood by adults whilst young people may be oblivious to adult concerns yet instead of developing mechanisms for consultation and negotiation which involve young people and help them play a part in decision making the response of adults is generally to override young peoples wishes more often than not with the backing of the public authorities through its national strategy for neighbourhood renewal nsnr the government places considerable importance on active citizenship and community partnerships that involve young people there is equal emphasis on controlling antisocial behaviour and getting communities to work together however the spinoffs from these new arrangements are not always positive and in some cases may even have unfortunate consequences for the communities they are designed to help the recently introduced curfew legislation is a case in point from august this year local authorities and the police were given powers to apply for curfew orders forcing young people up to the age of off the streets between the hours of pm and am although curfew legislation has been introduced with good intent there are fears that its practice may inhibit rather than enhance community regeneration and provoke rather than discourage youth disaffection notwithstanding the fact that the legislation breaches childrens human rights imposing curfews challenges the notion of young people as responsible citizens and potentially taints the majority because of the actions of the few it also risks discriminating against the least affluent evidence shows that children from more wealthy families are most likely to be escorted between commercialised leisure opportunities or to be at home in any case the areabased approach to curfews may even exacerbate inequalities between neighbourhoods there is a fear that the local authorities most likely to impose a curfew are those whose communities are already close to the edge of society where poor quality environments offer little for young people to do in the first place the imposition of a curfew would add to the bleakness of these places and further contribute to a society of haves and have nots there is also a very real possibility of a displacement effect as particular neighbourhoods adopt the curfew and herd young people towards other generally better off areas where they are viewed with even greater suspicion and hostility one of the main arguments against curfews is that they reinforce a view that the public domain is adult territory to which young people have only limited entitlement and then only with the sanction of their elders and betters throughout the curfew debate there has been no attempt to incorporate the views of young people about how they see the places where they live and play this is at the heart of the problem as much neighbourhood conflict arises from a poor understanding among adults of how children use and relate to public space children have a very strong sense of place and public spaces are vital for developing social networks and selfconfidence they are areas where young people learn about the world and have fun and crucially where they can exercise freedom and exert control it is interesting to note that young people adapt their environment to meet their needs green spaces become football pitches and multistorey car parks turn into skateboard parks allowing young people to take responsibility for their own public spaces rather than keeping them at home can produce huge benefits for both the young participants and the community in general young voices in regeneration is a national partnership programme developed by groundwork and save the children which aims to find practical ways of enabling all young people to play an active part in improving the physical environment of their neighbourhoods the programme has demonstrated the extent of poor communications between adults and children and the need for intermediary agencies to broker negotiation by working with adults and young people alike often what young people want is very simple a place to gather and meet friends what adults want is usually just as simple to know that their children are safe and are able to grow and develop without drifting into antisocial behaviour children as citizens have a fundamental right and entitlement to be involved in shaping their own communities only through regular participation will children develop a sense of communal responsibility and the skills needed to make a positive impact on their neighbourhoods much is happening and the government has made huge strides with the development of the nsnr however there is still a long way to go before childrens participation becomes normal and routine of course this isnt just a job for politicians it depends on us all much more needs to be done to widen the debate about childrens participation within the uk so that it becomes a compelling issue not just for professionals but for all adults and communities professor hugh matthews is director of the centre for children and youth at university college northampton the report children and community regeneration creating better neighbourhoods was written for save the children and the regeneration charity groundwork and is available from save the children publications tel

text: group solidarity and mutual trust are the key factors behind the growing success of quaker social actions qsa microcredit project street cred which helps unemployed women in east london to develop their own enterprises women working on the project join borrowing circles groups of five women who come together and support each other as they establish their respective businesses startup loans are issued on condition of the groups approval and access to future loans depends on each member of the group making repayments as agreed with street cred staff the circle is the real driver behind the project said claire caffrey street cred coordinator its a fantastic substitute for all the credits and checks required by high street banks the borrowing circle brings the women together and generates real trust and support she added the concept of the borrowing circle originates from the world famous grameen bank in bangladesh by far the most successful microcredit operation in the developing or developed world after a sponsored research trip to bangladesh qsa decided to apply this methodology to an urban setting and created street cred the active womens group based at ascot hall community centre in canning town is made up of five local women setting up businesses in dressmaking hairdressing the production and importing of african curios and in one instance buying and selling a special kind of fish stew from central africa we learn a great deal from one another and the more we learn the more we can attract other women said elli the groups voluntary coordinator perhaps then some of us can act as mentors to new women trying to get started in business we hope that the more successful we become the more we can attract other women to what we are doing she said street cred was specifically designed to help unemployed women access the business support training advice and finance necessary to establish an enterprise women have remained the focus for the project as qsa believes that business services are rarely tailored specifically towards women and take little account of factors such as childcare confidence or language barriers faced by some people from black and minority ethnic groups this may be reflected in government statistics which reveal that only one in four businesses are established by women elli whose own business is called pressing on enterprise thinks that the great deal of talk in public circles about equality and inclusion is simply not borne out in reality women are always excluded from the type of business support they need at street cred we respect one another and take each other seriously she said an ongoing problem for street creds entrepreneurs is the issue of benefits a demotivating factor for some of the women who understandably are fearful about the threat to their benefits if they start trading i think the benefits agency is living in another world said elli none of us wants to be on benefits we want to empower ourselves but its risky and takes time to establish a business the benefits agency should be working with us to remove this barrier in partnership with other organisations qsas street cred staff have been lobbying the treasury for greater flexibility within the benefits system the government is listening and it does see the problem said judith moran qsas acting director i think in the longer term there will be an answer the next year promises to be busy for the active womens group which is focusing on professional training finding business mentors and securing a stall to be used by the whole group at rathbone market in canning town

text: around one in nine youngsters in the uk will run away for at least one night before they turn according to a report on youth homelessness released today the childrens society study said that poor relationships between parents and their children are the major cause of young people running away from home the report said that children in stepfamilies are three times more likely to run away or be thrown out of the family home than those living with two parents and children in single parent families are twice as likely to run away or be forced to leave the childrens societys chief executive ian sparks said the research proved that the most significant factor in running away is the quality of relationships between children and parents and called for more family mediation to help reduce tension between parents and children the study entitled home run families and young runaways was based on a survey of teenagers aged to in schools across the uk researchers also carried out interviews with young runaways an estimated unders run away from home or from care every year and of them are forced to leave by parents or carers about one in seven of those who run away end up suffering violence or sexual abuse especially those who sleep rough the research comes ahead of a government report on young runaways due to be published by the social exclusion unit young runaways in their own words the childrens journalism agency childrens express was commissioned by the social exclusion unit to interview young runaways as part of its consultation process kevin from birmingham first ran away from home when he was because of his poor relationship with his stepfather he has run away many times since and now lives in a hostel i would never have run away if it wasnt for my stepdad i used to go home when he wasnt in to see my mum he said it got to the point where i slept rough in an old bus down the road in the middle of winter with no blankets just so i didnt have to go home kevin never told his mother that he was living on the streets he describes the experience as incredibly lonely and scary and says he does not want anyone to go through what he endured before considering running away young people should speak to someone first to get to the core of the issue he advises my life would have been much better if i hadnt run away he now helps the childrens society with promotional work aimed at warning other young people about the dangers of running away john from london ran away when he experienced troubles at home a year ago he spent about a month living rough on the streets of central london i slept in a subway next to charing cross station and managed to get blankets from homeless friends id met on the streets he said during his time on the street john saw drug abuse violence and young people boys and girls forced into prostitution a homeless friend told him about the london connection a day centre for homeless young people where he presently spends the majority of his time project workers have helped him find accommodation in various hostels he has completed a computer course and applied to go to college i could never recommend running away he says he feels that the authorities do not do enough to help people in his position independence is about the only positive thing this experience has taught me but id still like to go home soon ruth from birmingham had been in care since she was and first ran away from a childrens home at the age of she says that running away was partly due to her unhappiness within the care system she found places in hostels but is unsure of their merits theyre not always a better alternative to living on the streets often girls live with the constant threat of rape i was actually threatened text: superwoman is a myth twentyfive years after author shirley conran made millions by telling us that life was too short to stuff a mushroom new research shows women still believe they cannot have children and a career without feeling stressed exhausted and guilty four out of five british mothers resent women such as victoria beckham and cherie blair who are feted for coping with both family and highpressure jobs and more than half of women dont believe that their partner plays a significant role in the juggling act that is daily family life for most many women can rattle off to the nearest quarter of an hour where they are going to be during the day said fiona keyte of analysts publicis who carried out the nationwide study all too often husbands dont feature mothers are also very cynical about images and advertisements which portray women as brilliant and ordered and perfect they know that life is simply not like that eightynine per cent of women identified pop star victoria beckham as a show mum a career woman who never appears late or with a sick child per cent put the duchess of york and cherie blair a highprofile qc who earns far more than her husband the prime minister in the same category women object to the idea that such figures serve as role models to working mothers i really did once think that wed be the first generation that could have it all said ann finlay a yearold solicitor in edinburgh who has a sixyearold daughter it just hasnt happened im lucky my employers are very supportive but its still a huge effort to keep everything together even after we found a good au pair and a nursery im constantly negotiating and juggling there are days when i just know i cant leave work later than and if were let down by one of our helpers i face chaos for days its a constant stress that our mothers and grandmothers didnt have because they took or years off work more than half of the mothers surveyed identified themselves as undervalued overcriticised and tired they said key concerns were lack of time and the safety of their children women interviewed in depth said they did not regret having children for one moment but felt that the best years of their lives had passed and they now had little time for themselves kathy a yearold living in sheffield with two children told researchers by the time youve read to them bathed them put them to bed done the washingup and cleaned the kitchen its time to go to bed and then you have to start all over again emma from birmingham said i wish id known what kids would do to my life i wouldnt be without them but id like to have made more of a career out of my life first shirley conran first wife of design guru terence touched a nerve with millions of women when she published superwoman a selfhelp guide in as well as avoiding complicated cookery the book advised women to avoid unnecessary housework and sweep dirt under the rug it was the first time the notion of a worklife balance between career and family received popular recognition the reality for most working women is that finding childcare and balancing work and family life is still incredibly difficult in the uk today said stephen burke director of the daycare trust there is still only one childcare place for every seven children under the age of eight and british parents pay the highest childcare bills in europe until we see much greater investment in affordable childcare women will continue to struggle on a daily basis and their children will miss out recent research confirms that britain still has lower levels of childcare provision than almost every other european country meanwhile while businesses satisfy our demand for a society with shops and services open hours a day seven days a week per cent of families have a parent who works at weekends the number is expected to double by even when men are offering to do things for them said fiona keyte most women believe that men wont think three steps ahead in the way that they do the greater burden of looking after children almost always still rests with the woman they would certainly be much happier if that reality was reflected in the way that women are featured in adverts and the media bensummerskillobservercouk

text: talented businesswomen are to be given government help to break through a menonly culture into british boardrooms following new evidence that nearly half of the countrys top companies have no female directors research led by the solicitorgeneral harriet harman shows that the number of ftse firms with at least one woman on the board has fallen for the third year running the top performers in the ftse list of britains top companies were more than half as likely as the bottom to have women directors suggesting that sexist attitudes may hold firms back the best performer for women was marks amp spencer which is enjoying a revival after years of complaints that it did not know what women shoppers wanted a quarter of its directors are female including two in executive directorships the most powerful positions the former head of mi dame stella rimington is its newest recruit the findings come as patricia hewitt the trade and industry secretary draws up measures to be published next month to ensure that firms nurture female talent she is disappointed by female representation in the city and concerned that sexist attitudes will damage competitiveness by holding back talented employees hewitt is considering recommendations from denise kingsmill the governments equal pay adviser that firms should be forced to publish in their annual reports their strategies for promoting womens careers such as encouraging flexible working and mentoring schemes where senior women encourage junior ones kingsmill has warned that the major factor in the pay gap is now womens failure to reach the top jobs where salaries are highest harman said the message you get as a woman in a company with an allmale board is that somehow you dont count yet once you get women in other women further down achieve their potential faster she began the ftse females project with two thinktanks the industrial society and the fawcett society as a backbench mp before being recalled to the government in june she will present the findings to a conference this week

text: women like nicola horlick who hold down a demanding job and raise a family are usually described as having it all they seem to exemplify the s feminist ideal but recent research suggests that when it comes to deciding whether to return to work after starting a family most women feel they have no choice insurer norwich union found that although per cent of mothers return to work only per cent of those are keen to further their careers the overwhelming majority per cent start working again because they need the money these find ings were supported by a survey by ariel nonbio which found that six out of working mothers would prefer to ditch their careers if money were no object kate maycock spokesperson for the pressure group the mothers union believes its a simple case of women not receiving enough financial assistance it is not a question of choice but a question of economic necessity this situation may improve in the last budget labour promised more help for families last month it raised the working families tax credit where one parent is working from to a week as of april statutory paid maternity leave will be extended for employees from weeks to weeks and statutory maternity pay will rise from to a week but parent groups such as the maternity alliance claim uk parents are still worse off than those in the rest of europe government statistics also indicate that people in the uk now spend more of their income on running their households spending on leisure items such as holidays tv video and audio equipment has risen by more than per cent since the s is this why women feel pressured to return to work not according to cary cooper professor of occupational psychology at umist in manchester he says blue collar mothers work because they need the money they are on the breadline so they need two earners in the family lower middle class mothers work because they want to be able to pay for things for their children that they couldnt otherwise afford middle class and upper middle class mothers where there has been the biggest increase in working mothers dont do it for the money they feel the only work that is valued is paid work outside the house they do it for their own selfesteem

text: wackford squeers would be proud the government believes in the reasonable chastisement of small children it said last week announcing it would not follow the scottish executive in banning smacking this qualification is quite good enough to protect toddlers from being seriously hurt says health minister jacqui smith it would be sad enough to find iain duncan smith and his eccentric reminiscers for a happier victorian era prosecuting such nonsense but for a new labour government to be doing so is truly depressing it is unlawful to hit another adult whether you think such chastisement reasonable or not it is also unlawful to subject an adult to corporal punishment why it should therefore be acceptable to hit children who have none of the strength to resist or hit back is incomprehensible it should not take cases such as those of victoria climbie or jasmine beckford to remind us of the dangers of validating adult authority to hurt children every year in britain children die from cruelty at the hands of their carers all too often they are victims of a mentality which condones the assault on children for far too many parents that offers an excuse for the first step on a route to abuse supporters of the hitting of children often claim that abuse rather than reasonable chastisement only happens in single parent or feckless households this is not true research carried out by the department of health itself in found that per cent of children in stable twoparent families had been hit with an implement and one third had been punished severely in other words such abuse is all too commonplace it is not just reputedly liberal scandinavia but countries including germany austria and cyprus which have now outlawed the hitting of children none of them shows any of the claimed disbenefits such as increased juvenile crime or school truancy alleged all too often by its supporters all the evidence is that corporal punishment is a determining factor in the development of violent behaviour itself in later life and if we believe that children learn by example in almost everything else loving honesty generosity it is unsustainable to think that violence is the one behaviour pattern they will not see fit to follow above all what was disturbing about last weeks government announcement was the sense that it is another attempt to accommodate a mystical middle england rather than to do what is right no better demonstration of labour embarrassment over this exists than the appearance of the thoroughly decent foreign office minister denis macshane on bbcs question time last thursday he dutifully played the role of wackford squeers with no conviction whatsoever of course no parent should be prosecuted for an isolated slap but hitting children is always wrong

text: a labour backbench revolt was brewing last night over an expected government announcement today that will tell parents in england and wales they can continue to smack their children without interference from the state alan milburn the health secretary will reject pressure from childrens charities to follow the example of scotland where the devolved administration is preparing to outlaw all physical punishment of underthrees ministers have decided that they need to make minimal changes to english law to comply with a ruling by the european court of human rights that the uk failed to protect a boy whose stepfather beat him with a cane the european judges cast doubt on the notion that british parents could commit an assault on their own children if this was done as reasonable chastisement but mr milburn is expected to declare that parents should be able to decide within reason how to punish their children without the nanny state interfering in their family life although he may tighten the law to ban punishment with canes and belts he is expected to leave the courts to determine the boundaries of reasonable chastisement david hinchliffe labour chairman of the commons health committee said the government faced a revolt on the issue there is a lot of unease among a significant number of labour mps about lack of progress on this question we cant have an effective child protection system while we preserve this archaic concept of reasonable chastisement the tragic death of victoria climbi started with slaps and smacks which escalated into terrible abuse mr hinchliffe a social worker for nearly years before becoming an mp said he had experience of being challenged in court by lawyers arguing that the marks of abuse on a childs body were the result of appropriate parental discipline we cant hope to prevent violence against children when our law and our society continue to send the wrong messages to parents he said the scottish executive decided in september to ban the smacking of children under three hitting any child over the head shaking them or striking them with an implement it also plans to make it illegal for childcare centres and childminders to administer corporal punishment this followed a ukwide consultation on the issue after the european court ruling in deciding not to follow scotlands lead mr milburn is understood to have been influenced by a survey commissioned by the government which showed that of parents thought they should decide how they disciplined their children this ran counter to a mori poll in showing that of the british public would support children having equal legal protection against assault if they could be sure that parents would not be prosecuted for trivial smacks tony blair admitted in that he had smacked his children occasionally when they were really naughty or did something nasty to another child but he said he always regretted it because there were lots of ways of disciplining a child and i dont think belting is the best way the childrens charity the nspcc said last night we are deeply concerned that the government may come out with proposals that leave children less protected south of the scottish border anything less than the scottish proposals would signal to parents in england that it is ok to hit babies and toddlers which is an extremely dangerous message young children could be hurt more easily than most people think it said it is never acceptable to cross the line and hit babies and toddlers we find it incredible that a government so committed to child protection would deliver such a cruel blow to efforts to keep babies and toddlers from harm we hope they will think again an alliance of more than organisations backing legal reform against smacking was mobilising last night to challenge the governments decision children are unbeatable was preparing to present evidence that infants under months are four times more likely to be homicide victims than the rest of the population at least one being killed every fortnight threequarters of parents smack their babies in the first year of life mostly as a result of irritation or anger the alliance said of oneyearold children were hit at least once a week by their parents

text: homeless families are being threatened with having their children taken away from them as families were nearly years ago the prospect of a return to the traumatic family breakups exposed in the s tv play cathy come home follows a high court ruling last may housing experts warn that some children face christmas in care weve dealt with a string of cases across the country in the last three months where social services are telling homeless families their children should be taken away and fostered or placed in local authority care said russell campbell chief solicitor at shelter councils are saying the only service they are obliged to provide is care for the children cashstrapped councils short of housing won legal challenges to a yearold requirement to help families with children in need they say that housing parents as well goes beyond their legal obligation tina smith from north london lives in one bedroom in a hostel with her two children aged and we have an eviction order for november she said the council has repeatedly told me they will take the children into care but they are offering nothing for me im terribly frightened it would be my very worst nightmare and its getting closer all the time smith has been told she became intentionally homeless because her former partner sold their house and then spent the proceeds that doesnt make any difference now im too terrified to tell the children whats going on no one will help i dont know what to do she said in south london the collins family has moved four times in five years from one temporary accommodation to another after dave collinss employer closed down they have four children of between five and years and are about to receive a possession order for their flat we turned down one tiny flat because it was miles away from the childrens schools the council has now said that if we become homeless again they will involve social services which means taking the children said sarah collins the children dont know i cant bear to tell them my husband is now ill with extremely bad stress weve spent five of the most important years of the kids childhood just moving around and now this you cant even rent privately because nobody wants to take you if youre on benefits the children act of put the needs of children above all other considerations in offering council services and was invoked regularly by homeless families to secure accommodation however this use was successfully chal lenged in court this year by the london boroughs of lambeth and barnet which are both short of accommodation for text: the childrens charity nspcc last night claimed that the governments refusal to ban smacking will contribute to further suffering of children at the hands of abusive parents it released results of a survey of frontline child protection workers showing had direct personal experience of cases of abuse or neglect involving unacceptable levels of physical punishment twothirds thought a law to protect children from being hit would strengthen the ability of social workers to intervene earlier to protect a child at risk of abuse and said the current law permitting reasonable chastisement sent the wrong message to potentially abusive parents mary marsh the charitys director appealed to ministers to think again about their negative response to a ruling by the european court of human rights that the law in england failed to give children adequate protection this survey of social work professionals shows there is a link between physical punishment and abusive behaviour i am confident the majority of parents will unite with us to support changes to the law that are not an attack on them but on the significant minority of abusers who use the current law to excuse severe beatings she said the government reviewed the law on smacking after the european court ruled that the uk failed to protect a boy whose stepfather beat him with a cane the scottish executive responded with plans to ban hitting children under three and outlaw hitting any child around the head with implements but the government decided last month against changing the law in england and wales after widespread consultation alan milburn the health secretary rejected the advice of nearly all the organisations involved in child protection that smacking should be banned his decision to leave parents free to smack was supported by religious groups and the majority of individuals who responded to the consultation the nspcc survey was designed to explore the views of of its staff who were most closely involved in frontline child protection and family support their average experience in this type of work was years it found thought a law to protect children from being hit would help their work and wanted a ban on smacking babies and toddlers and on hitting any child with an implement more than half the frontline staff thought parents often tried to excuse abusive behaviour as reasonable chastisement and a further said abusive parents did this occasionally when the child protection workers were asked about cases with which they had been involved said at least half of the abuse started with light smacks that became harder and harder hits this escalation happened occasionally according to a further quarter of respondents the government claimed its m advertising campaign to attract more people to a career in social work was an overwhelming success in the first six weeks it attracted almost calls to a recruitment information line and more than visits to a website

text: ministers are to take emergency action to prevent homeless families having their children taken into care after the observer exposed the threat to hundreds of parents stephen byers the cabinet minister responsible for housing will ensure that councils are legally obliged to keep families together the news follows a landmark court case which triggered uncomfortable memories of the era of the tv play cathy come home which famously showed social workers forcibly removing children from their parents the court of appeal ruled last month that councils had a duty to rehouse only children in the event of homelessness not their parents as well this meant that councils could fulfil their legal duties simply by putting children into care but the housing charity shelter warned that it set an alarming precedent last week the observer revealed how four children in a yorkshire family had been taken into care after their parents were evicted from their council home having fallen into rent arrears byers is now drafting an amendment to the governments homelessness bill which is due back before the house of lords in january to compel housing and social services departments to work together in finding solutions for families a separate amendment will reinforce the need for social services to keep families united a package has been put together to overcome the issue that shelter and the observer have raised said a source close to the minister a spokeswoman for shelter said it was absolutely delighted director chris holmes said it is vital that a change in the law is made to prevent families being torn apart simply because they are homeless

text: four children in a yorkshire family have been taken into care after their parents lost their home the move a return to the harrowing breakups common among homeless families until years ago is about to be copied throughout britain councils are exploiting a new legal loophole to save cash housing experts warn that hundreds of other children face in care they had hoped that local authorities would step back from the threat which emerged after a legal ruling earlier this year mary smith from yorkshire has four children aged five seven and she and her partner got into rent arrears in their council house in the summer partly because their council reclaimed an overpayment of benefit two months ago the family was evicted we were given a bed and breakfast for four weeks says mary but i was told that after that i would have to find somewhere to live myself and i would get no more help after we lost the bed and breakfast in october we were completely homeless my partner couldnt cope with it and went to live in a caravan i slept with the kids in the car after three days the social services came along they took the kids i agreed to it but that was because they said if i didnt agree voluntarily they would get a care order it was awful the kids had some problems with behaviour but that was just because theyd been coming and going they didnt know where they were theyd be fine with somewhere to live theyve been split up and they miss each other terribly two children have been placed in a foster home and one in another the fourth child in now in a residential school he has run away sev eral times it hurts and hurts its tearing the whole family apart my fiveyear old has been poorly and off school and they never even told me the children keep asking when they are coming home an adviser with shelter the homelessness charity confirmed that the children were being well cared for well fed and well nourished russell campbell chief solicitor at shelter said homelessness has become a valid trigger for removing children from their families since the court of appeal upheld the new legal position last month were seeing more and more cases like this the children act had until now offered protection for families who fell through the housing safety net it put the needs of the children above all other considerations and was used to require councils to provide accommodation for families but the recent judgment accepted that councils need only offer accommodation to children a spokeswoman for the london borough of lambeth whose legal action secured the new loophole said yesterday it was an accident that our case turned out in this way we want to help people into a home of their own but shelter is in contact with families throughout britain who expect their children to be taken into care within weeks the tv play cathy come home in which depicted social workers forcibly taking the children of a homeless family into care led to major changes in the law karen buck mp a member of the commons work and pensions select committee said the government has asked for evidence that these court judgments were impacting on real families that evidence has now clearly emerged the government must act to close this loophole before homelessness breaks up more families mary did have some good news on friday she found a house and has been told her children might be returned to her but it will be too difficult to release them all before christmas if the children came back said mary their daddy would come back too we could be a normal family again theyve been crying for him no one should have to go through this ever

text: the government is to give women new rights to find out if they earn the same as their male colleagues under a package of measures announced yesterday aimed at raising womens pay and bolstering their career prospects patricia hewitt the trade and industry secretary wants big companies to disclose each year their approach to employing women as well as conducting pay reviews of the most junior and senior staff responding to a report by denise kingsmill the lawyer commissioned by the government to conduct a review of women at work ms hewitt called for a cultural change among employers an important part of this cultural change comes from providing better information to employees and to shareholders on a companys record on equal pay and employment ms hewitt said the government is determined to ensure that women do not have to face a stark choice between being a mother and a successful employee she added the ministers endorsement of the detailed analysis by mrs kingsmill follows the governments move earlier this year to give women the right to ask to work parttime when returning after having a baby the government is trying to avoid new legislation by encouraging companies to comply voluntarily and has pledged to adopt the policies in its own departments but ministers did not support all of the proposals from mrs kingsmill who spoke to the chief executives of big companies while conducting her research on why women earned less than men and were clustered in lower paid jobs the government failed to support the suggestion that companies should receive a tax credit for providing training for higher paid jobs or recruiting and training women for jobs in which they are un derrepresented nor was the government willing to set up a new academic centre of excellence to initiate research on womens careers but mrs kingsmill who is also deputy chairman of the competition commission and nonexecutive director of a number of public companies said she was delighted with the governments response to her work she would like to see the pay gap which took years to reach from halve in the next five years her aim is to persuade companies that it is in their best interests to support womens careers because not doing so was a waste of a natural resource however the governments policy of relying on voluntary compliance by companies met with a mixed response gail cartmail equalities officer for the manufacturing and science and finance union said left to their own devices employers will do nothing to bridge the pay gap compulsory pay audits are the only way forward john monks tuc general secretary called on the government to introduce legisla tion if the voluntary approach failed to work but the cbi said employers should not get all the blame the main causes are the large numbers of women working in lowpaid sectors and many women take career breaks or work parttime because of childcare responsibilities said its director of human resources susan anderson ruth lea head of policy at the institute of directors accused the government of witchhunting employers we all believe in equal pay but there are good reasons why women are paid less for instance marriage and children

text: women workers were today expected to be given new rights to find out if male colleagues are paid more in a move aimed at closing the gender pay gap companies refusing to provide information could be taken to an employment tribunal the plan is to encourage a more open culture in the workplace so that women can find out if they are being paid comparable rates to colleagues of similar experience trade and industry secretary patricia hewitt is expected to make the announcement as part of her response to a report by denise kingsmill the governments advisor on equal pay unions will welcome the move although they want the government to go further and force employers to conduct pay reviews to make sure women are not being paid less than men the kingsmill report is expected to recommend naming and shaming companies which fail to take action to close the pay gap between men and women ms hewitt told bbc radio s today programme what we are doing is putting in place through the employment bill an equal pay questionnaire which will mean that instead of going off to a tribunal to find out whether or not you are getting equal pay you can actually ask your employer in the first place this is nothing to do with red tape it is about making sure that women in the workplace can find out whether they are getting fair pay compared with men doing the same job if they find out with that information that they are getting equal pay we will avoid unnecessary tribunal cases if the employer didnt intend to discriminate it may trigger him to look at the problem and to deal with his pay structure where a woman brings an equal pay claim she is entitled to get that information in any case ms hewitt said that the legislation would not allow employees to go on fishing expeditions to find out the pay scales of people in different jobs which she said would be a breach of privacy she said that the new rules would help establish whether bonuses were being awarded in a discriminatory way giving men a cash boost not available to women doing the same jobs

text: the government today announced moves aimed at closing the gender pay gap saying it wanted to prevent women facing a stark choice between being a mother and a successful employee firms were urged to launch pay reviews to make sure their female employees are not being underpaid larger companies will have to publish details of how they train and recruit staff under proposals unveiled by the trade and industry secretary patricia hewitt women will also find it easier to get information from their employers about whether they are being paid less than their male colleagues companies refusing to provide information could be taken to an employment tribunal though there will also be legislation to prevent employees going on fishing expeditions to find out the pay scales of people in different jobs ms hewitt said there was much more to do to close the pay gap between men and women which now stands at unequal pay was not a problem that could be fixed overnight because it differed between industries occupations regions and people of different ages she said our proposals will help but what is also needed is a cultural change among employers to properly value womens contribution to business success she said that too many women were becoming detached from wellpaid jobs by motherhood they end up losing out and it is reflected in the continuing pay gap the government is determined to ensure that women do not have to face a stark choice she said the womens minister barbara roche added that the government wanted women to reach their full potential and was determined to give them more choices about how they balance work and home responsibilities the governments equal pay adviser denise kingsmill prepared a report leading to todays announcement based on consultations with companies trade unions voluntary organisations and public sector bodies unions welcomed todays announcement but many believe the government should go further and order companies to carry out statutory pay reviews

text: working women are to get new legal rights to find out whether male colleagues earn more than them as part of a government crusade to close the pay gap between the sexes patricia hewitt the trade and industry secretary will target the secrecy shrouding some workplaces where discussion of salary is banned allowing employers to get away with underpaying women she will also promise action to stop women in highly paid careers dropping out when they have children and taking menial posts that fit around family life she will call for an end to the excessive long hours culture in british offices hewitt who will unveil plans at a summit of unions and employers on wednesday will ask her own cabinet colleagues to lead the way by tackling excessive working hours in whitehall the fundamental problem as she sees it is women being detached from highquality posts through motherhood said a source close to hewitt the evidence shows the pay gap is bigger among lower social groups poorer paid unskilled workers and thats where our main focus is denise kingsmill the governments adviser on equal pay will also seek to name and shame firms failing to act on equal pay when she unveils the findings of a review on closing the pay gap she wants companies to be forced to publish their strategies on women employees pay and prospects in their annual reports embarrassing unenlightened employers into action the idea risks being unpopular with business however and hewitt will say it needs further consideration kingsmill will also recommend voluntary moves employers could take to show they are serious such as making senior managers bonuses dependent on ensuring equal pay for staff or encouraging flexible working for mothers the moves follow a string of highprofile pay battles including the recent case of julie bower an investment analyst with schroder securities she resigned after getting a bonus of only when two male analysts received million between them a tribunal found the amount was calculated and intended to make her feel unwanted and that she would not have been treated in that way but for the fact that she was a woman schroders was found guilty of sex discrimination and compensation yet to be set could be up to m controversially hewitt is expected to admit that the pay gap women earn p for every pound a man does may never be entirely closed kingsmill has suggested only that it could be halved in five years the key however will be kingsmills ideas on making it easier for women to win fair wages without going to industrial tribunal she has recommended that women be able to force disclosure from their bosses of how much a named male colleague earns however the government fears this would breach mens right to privacy instead the forthcoming employment bill will give female staff statutory rights to ask employers if equivalent men in the firm are paid more than them without the exact amount being disclosed in some companies disclosing salaries to peers is banned leaving women unaware that they are underpaid employers refusing to answer could be taken to tribunal with their refusal counting against them in the ruling ministers hope that in most cases bosses will simply give in without a tribunal being necessary the new rights stop short of demands from the equal opportunities commission and the tuc that firms be forced to carry out pay reviews comparing all workers salaries the government has firmly rejected the idea unions also fear kingsmill has focused on highpaid corporate women while per cent of the pay gap involves women in the two lowest social classes meanwhile the cbi is expected to resist any form of compulsion on employers to close the pay gap it is too easy to say it is the employers fault it is much more to do with social factors and barriers to participation in the workplace said a spokesman we are waiting to see what this will mean for companies in practice
